question: According to IHL, when should the search for, collection, and evacuation of the dead be carried out?

options.A: Whenever circumstances permit, and particularly after an engagement, all parties involved in the conflict must, without delay, search for the dead, without adverse distinction.
options.B: After the general close of military operations, parties must employ all efforts to search for, collect and evacuate the dead.
options.C: After an engagement, every party to the conflict must collect its own dead, as every party is only responsible for the members of its own armed forces.
options.D: As soon as circumstances permit, especially after an engagement, all parties must search for the dead through all possible measures, including by allowing humanitarian organizations to do so.

question: According customary IHL, who is responsible for the search for and collection of the dead?

options.A: All parties to the conflict.
options.B: Only States.
options.C: The ICRC or other humanitarian organizations.
options.D: States, with the support of humanitarian organizations.

question: Which of the following actions constitute violations of IHL?

options.A: Carrying the dead away from the place where they died, since they should be buried in the theatre of hostilities where they fell.
options.B: Despoiling or pillaging the dead, unless such an action effectively contributes to the military operations of a party to the conflict - in which case despolling would be allowed.
options.C: Despoiling the dead or pillaging their personal belongings, regardless of the objects' nature.
options.D: Mutilating the bodies of the deceased.

question: How does IHL govern the handling of human remains?

options.A: The dead must be buried in a collective grave regardless of identification status.
options.B: Each party to the conflict must take all feasible measures to prevent the dead from being despoiled.
options.C: Parties to a conflict are required to conduct an autopsy on all deceased individuals to determine the cause of death.
options.D: The dead must be buried, but only if they are identified as members of the armed forces of a party to the conflict.

question: According to customary IHL, who can request the return of the remains of the dead in an armed conflict?

options.A: The party to which the deceased belonged, including organized armed groups during a non-international armed conflict.
options.B: The party to which the deceased belonged or their next of kin but only during international armed conflicts.
options.C: Friends and family of the deceased.
options.D: The party to which the deceased belonged or their next of kin in both international and non-international armed conflicts.

question: According to IHL, what are some of the duties that must be observed when returning the remains of the dead?

options.A: Facilitate the return of the remains, be it bodies or ashes.
options.B: Return the personal effects of the deceased together with their remains.
options.C: Identify all deceased persons before repatriating their remains.
options.D: When possible, return the remains of all members of the same religious and social groups together.

question: What procedures shall be followed when burying the dead during an armed conflict?

options.A: If possible, they shall be buried in accordance with the rites of their own religion.
options.B: They shall be kept in individual graves, as collective graves are prohibited by IHL in all circumstances.
options.C: They shall be kept in individual graves, unless circumstances do not permit their use.
options.D: When possible, graves should be grouped according to the nationality of the deceased.

question: According to IHL, when can the dead be cremated?

options.A: Only with the express consent of the next of kin of the deceased.
options.B: In exceptional circumstances, namely because of imperative reasons of hygiene or on account of the religion of the deceased.
options.C: It is always prohibited under IHL to cremate the dead.
options.D: In accordance with the express wish of the deceased.

question: Do the parties to an conflict have to identify the dead under IHL?

options.A: Yes¨, and they need to deal respectfully with every deceased person, without adverse distinction.
options.B: Yes, being an obligation of result, failure by parties to a conflict to identify the dead is a violation of IHL.
options.C: No, the obligation to account for the dead is one of means and as such all parties must employ their best efforts and all means available to identify the dead.
options.D: Yes, however this is only an obligation for States. Given the limited resources of non-state actors, they must simply make every possible effort to identify the dead.

question: According to IHL, what kind of information about the dead must be recorded by parties to an armed conflict?

options.A: All information available before the disposal of their bodies.
options.B: It is sufficient to register their name, affiliation, and cause of death.
options.C: For non-international armed conflicts, it suffices to record the cause of death.
options.D: The location of the graves only, as the information on each of the dead could then be recorded after the end of the conflict.

question: What obligations do parties to an armed conflict have under IHL regarding missing persons?

options.A: Parties shall keep a record of all missing persons, which will be made available after the end of the conflict.
options.B: Parties must take all feasible measures to account for persons reported missing as a result of armed conflict.
options.C: Parties are not responsible for accounting for missing persons, as this is the responsibility of the Central Tracing Agency.
options.D: Parties shall keep a separate database of persons missing in relation to the conflict to avoid overlapping this data with that of persons missing due to other circumstances.

question: What are persons deprived of their liberty entitled to according to IHL?

options.A: To receive sufficient food, water, and clothing.
options.B: To be provided with adequate shelter.
options.C: To receive adequate medical attention.
options.D: To be paid a fair working rate for their labor.

question: Does the duty to provide adequate food to persons deprived of their liberty remain in the event of shortages caused by the armed conflict?

options.A: Yes, the obligation to provide persons deprived of their liberty with adequate food should always be complied with, even if food from the local civilian population has to be diverted for this end.
options.B: Yes, parties to the conflict must provide adequate food, however they are allowed to take into account the means available and local conditions. If they are unable to provide these basic needs, they must allow humanitarian agencies to provide assistance in their place.
options.C: No, the duty to provide food takes into account the reality of the armed conflict, and may be suspended in case there is a food shortage.
options.D: Yes, and in case of food shortages, preference can be given to those persons deprived of their liberty for reasons not related to the armed conflict.

question: According to IHL, what special conditions do women who have been deprived of their liberty benefit from?

options.A: They shall be treated in equality with men, benefiting from the same protection and basic provisions.
options.B: They shall be held separately from men, in cells dedicated for women, without exception.
options.C: They shall be held separately from men, except when accomodated with their families.
options.D: When detained, they shall be under the supervision of women.

question: What considerations must be made to prevent women from becoming victims of sexual violence during their deprivation of liberty, according to IHL?

options.A: No special consideration is made, since everyone is protected from sexual violence in armed conflicts without discrimination.
options.B: Women must be kept in quarters that are separate from men, except where families are accomodated as family units, and under the supervision of women.
options.C: Women should always be kept only with other women, even when there is a possibility to keep them accomodated with their families, to also prevent intrafamily violence.
options.D: Women should receive medical attention more frequently than men so as to identify possible signs of sexual violence early on.

question: According to IHL, what rules must be observed when detaining children?

options.A: To ensure their protection from harm, children must be held separately from adults in all circumstances.
options.B: Children must be held separately from adults, except where families are accomodated as family units.
options.C: If detained for taking part in the conflict, children do not benefit from special considerations.
options.D: Children can be held either separately or with adults, depending on their own preference.

question: According to customary IHL, where must detention centers be located?

options.A: The centers must be removed from the combat zone, unless the detainees have previously taken part in the hostilties.
options.B: The centers must be removed from the combat zone, especially if they accomodate civilian internees only.
options.C: Both internment and detention centers must be removed from the combat zone.
options.D: Their location depends on the structure available before the hostilitiies begin, as parties to the conflict often use common prison facilities for detention and internment purposes.

question: A soldier from State A, wearing the uniform of State B, infiltrated enemy lines for reconnaissance purposes, and was subsequently captured. What is his status under IHL?

options.A: The soldier was engaging in espionage and having fallen into the power of State B while not wearing his military uniform does not have the right prisoner of war status. He can be treated as a spy.
options.B: The soldier, being a member of the armed forces, benefits from combatant status and if captured, is considered a prisoner of war.
options.C: The soldier has lost his prisoner of war status, will be treated as a spy and can be tried accordingly.
options.D: Because the soldier was engaged in espionage, and not wearing his military uniform, he is now considered an unlawful combatant.

question: What conditions does customary IHL set concerning the premises where persons deprived of their liberty will be held?

options.A: Places of detention must safeguard the health and hygiene of persons deprived of their liberty.
options.B: The premises must be located near city centers to offer people deprived of their liberty with basic conditions to interact with civil life.
options.C: Detention centres must include areas dedicated to sports and the socialization of people deprived of their liberty.
options.D: The premises must include separate cells for those from different religious or ethnic groups.

question: What are the obligations regarding the personal belongings of persons deprived of their liberty in an armed conflict?

options.A: Personal belongings can be kept, used, or sold by the power detaining them, especially if they are of high economic value.
options.B: Only personal belongings with emotional value to the person deprived of liberty shall be properly kept and returned at the moment of release.
options.C: Persons deprived of their liberty shall be allowed to retain their personal belongings, which are protected from pillage.
options.D: Objects which can pose security threats or other similar concerns may be destroyed or disposed of by the detaining power.

question: Under IHL, can a detaining power take objects belonging to persons deprived of their liberty because they could be used in military operations?

options.A: Yes, it is allowed to take as war booty all objects that could be used in military operations which are in possession of persons deprived of their liberty, without exception.
options.B: Yes, it is allowed to take, as war booty, objects that could be used in military operations, except those used for personal protection, such as helmets and gas masks.
options.C: No, as this would constitute pillage, which is prohibited under IHL.
options.D: No, as this would give the detaining power an unfair military advantage. The only objects that can be kept as war booty are those with no military purpose.

question: A patrol from State X's unit has captured an enemy soldier from State Y. Taking him along would endanger the patrol’s mission and safety. Were he to be abandoned, he could disclose the patrol’s presence. The patrol leader kills the prisoner. Was this lawful under IHL?

options.A:
Killing the enemy soldier was unlawful. Should the patrol members fail to report the incident or to initiate proper legal steps, they would also be criminally responsible for
violating IHL.
options.B: It is absolutely prohibited under IHL to kill a prisoner of war. Such a killing can never be justified on the basis of military necessity. The patrol leader committed a war crime.
options.C: Killing the enemy soldier was not unlawful as the requirements of military necessity have been met.
options.D: The decision to kill the prisoner was unlawful and the patrol leader should instead have released him.

question: According to IHL, are parties to a conflict obliged to record the personal details of persons deprived of their liberty?

options.A: Yes, but only if the detaining power is notified that a person deprived of their liberty has been considered missing by their family or the power to which they belong.
options.B: Yes, and in international armed conflicts the detaining power may, as a last resort, use coercive measures to obtain this information from prisoners of war who are in any event bound to divulge their surname, first names, rank, date of birth and equivalent information.
options.C: No, as it would be difficult to obtain this information or verify it in conflict situations.
options.D: Yes, the detaining power has a duty to record the personal details of all persons deprived of their liberty.

question: According to IHL, is the duty to record the personal details of persons deprived of their liberty applicable in all armed conflicts?

options.A: Yes, except for those conflicts involving non-state armed groups only, where there is no involvement of state armed forces whatsoever.
options.B: Yes, however in both international and non international armed conflicts, the obligation is borne only by States.
options.C: No, since it would be unfair to require this duty from non-state armed groups.
options.D: Yes, it is in fact a customary law rule applicable in both international and non-international armed conflicts and to all parties.

question:
State Y and Z are engaged in an armed conflict. A soldier from State Y, wearing the camouflage uniform of his country’s
armed forces, is captured while gathering intelligence on State Z's troop movements. An interrogating officer from State Z tells the soldier that he will be treated as a spy and has no prisoner of war status. According to IHL, what treatment is the captured soldier entitled to?

options.A: If a soldier is captured while engaging in espionage behind enemy lines he loses prisoner of war status. The interrogating officer's judgement was correct.
options.B: Soldiers may use ruses to carry out their missions, and camouflage is a permitted ruse provided civilian clothing or the enemy uniform is not used during the intelligence gathering operation. The soldier is entitled to and must be treated as a prisoner of war.
options.C: A spy is one who gathers or attempts to gather intelligence within the zone of operations of a belligerent, secretly, under false pretences. Had the soldier not worn a camouflage uniform, he would have been entitled to prisoner of war status. However, he has forfeited this and can be treated as spy.
options.D: Members of the armed forces in uniform who obtain intelligence in the enemy zone of operation are not spies. The soldier's reconnaissance was a lawful combat activity and he is entitled to prisoner of war status upon capture.

question: Do detaining authorities have an obligation to allow the ICRC to access persons deprived of their liberty in an armed conflict?

options.A: Yes, in international armed conflicts, parties must allow the ICRC regular access to all persons deprived of their liberty.
options.B: It depends on how the conflict is classified, as in non-international armed conflicts, the ICRC may offer its services to the parties to the conflict but the parties are not obliged to accept this offer.
options.C: No, in both international and non-international conflicts, this service may be offered by the ICRC, but none of the parties are obliged to accept it.
options.D: Yes, in both international and non-international armed conflicts, parties to the conflict must allow the ICRC to access all persons deprived of their liberty.

question: What rights must the ICRC be accorded for them to conduct their visits in armed conflicts?

options.A: Access to all persons deprived of their liberty for reasons related to armed conflict, at all stages of their detention and in all places where they are held.
options.B: Authorization to inform the family of the detention of a relative and to ensure the exchange of news between persons deprived of their liberty and their families, whenever necessary.
options.C: The possibility of registering the identity of the persons deprived of their liberty.
options.D: Permission to repeat its visits on a regular basis and the possibility of talking freely and in private with the detainees of its choice.

question: What does the obligation to respect and ensure respect under IHL entail?

options.A: States are required to respect IHL and ensure that their own armed forces respect it. States may also ensure respect for IHL by other persons and groups under their control, although this is not mandatory.
options.B: The State's obligation to respect and ensure respect for IHL covers its own armed forces, other persons or groups acting in fact on its instructions, or under its direction or control.
options.C: The obligation to respect IHL is part of the States'  general obligation to respect international law and applicable only to situations of international armed conflicts.
options.D: None of the above.

question: According to IHL, who bears the obligation to respect and ensure respect of IHL rules?

options.A: States, including their own armed forces and other persons or groups acting in fact on their instructions, or under their direction or control.
options.B: In non-international armed conflicts, armed opposition groups must also respect, as a minimum, the IHL rules set forth in common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions.
options.C: Only States and those under their control must respect IHL rules, whether in international or non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: Non-state armed groups do not have an obligation to respect IHL, only international human rights law.

question: Does respect for IHL depend on reciprocity?

options.A: Yes. Respect for IHL is subject to reciprocity, both in international and non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: No. IHL affirms that the obligation to respect and ensure respect for IHL does not depend on reciprocity in situations of international armed conflicts. In non-international armed conflicts, however, this obligation does depend on reciprocity.
options.C: Yes. Compliance with IHL depends on the capability of the party to do so. State actors have more resources to implement IHL than non-state actors, which means that the principle of reciprocity does not apply to non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: No. Respect for IHL by one party does not depend on respect for IHL by another. IHL must be respected in all circumstances.

question: During recent engagements an infantry company commander expressed dissatisfaction with the small arms ammunition on issue. His subordinates suggest that the ammunition be altered. Which of the following options would be lawful under IHL?

options.A: The hard tips of the bullets could be cut with incisions so that they would flatten out on impact.
options.B: The tips of the bullets could be flattened slightly, so that they flatten on impact.
options.C: A and B would both be lawful.
options.D: The commander must not allow the ammunition to be tampered with in any way. The use of expanding or dumdum bullets is prohibited under customary IHL and banned by the Hague Declaration of 1899.

question: Under IHL, is it mandatory for States to have legal advisers in their armed forces?

options.A: Yes. It is mandatory for States to incorporate legal advisers into their military so they can advise military commanders on the application of IHL, but only when it comes to international armed conflicts.
options.B: No. States must have a legal adviser on the application of IHL only if they have signed and ratified Additional Protocol I of the Geneva Conventions, which contains this obligation.
options.C: No, however it is mandatory for States to provide legal advisers to commanders of their armed forces on the application of IHL, this rule being corollary to the obligation to respect and ensure respect for IHL.
options.D: Yes. Both State armed forces and opposition groups are also required to have legal advisors to ensure that IHL will be respected in the context of their military operations.

question: According to IHL, which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The obligation for States to make legal advisers available to advise military commanders on the application of IHL only applies to State armed forces.
options.B: Non-state armed groups are not legally required to have legal advisers therefore they have a lesser burden of respecting and ensuring respect of IHL.
options.C: Legal advisers can never be held criminally responsible for war crimes committed pursuant to their advice to military commanders.
options.D: States are obliged to make legal advisers available to advise the armed forces on the application of IHL.

question: According customary IHL, instruction in IHL within armed forces:

options.A: Is an obligation applicable to States in time of peace, as well as to parties to international or non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: Is an obligation applicable to States only in times of war, with no distinction between applicability in international armed conflicts or non-international armed conflicts
options.C: Requires that all members of the armed forces are familiar with every detail of IHL rules so that they are able to understand how to implement these rules in their functions and duties at every military engagement and have an appropriate response to specific situations in the battlefield.
options.D: Is not found in the practice of States that deploy contingents made available to the United Nations in the form of peacekeeping and peace-enforcement troops.

question: What does the obligation for States and parties to an armed conflict to provide instruction in IHL to their armed forces entail?

options.A: States and parties to the armed conflict must ensure that all members of their armed forces are totally familiar with every detail of IHL.
options.B: The obligation for commanders to instruct the armed forces under their command on IHL is limited to State actors, since there is no obligation for armed opposition groups to respect and ensure respect for IHL.
options.C: Where non-state armed groups are, for whatever reason, unable to instruct their members, they are required to allow the ICRC to disseminate IHL among their members.
options.D: Armed forces must be instructed on the essential rules of the law that are relevant to their actual functions.

question: What does customary IHL say about teaching IHL to civilians?

options.A: Customary IHL does not address dissemination of IHL to the civilian population, as civilians are not parties to armed conflicts.
options.B: States must encourage the teaching of IHL to the civilian population as widely as possible, including through training programmes and by facilitating courses through the provision of funds to organizations such as the National Red Cross or Red Crescent Society.
options.C: Law enforcement personnel (judiciary, police, prison personnel), as part of the civilian population and civil servants, are not particularly encouraged to be taught on IHL because they abide by different rules and procedures.
options.D: Civilian authorities who, in time of armed conflict, assume responsibilities in respect of the application of IHL, do not need to have previous training on IHL.

question: Under customary IHL, the obligation to encourage the teaching of IHL to the civilian popualtion:

options.A: Refers to a state's civil servants, in particular law enforcement personnel (judiciary, police, prison personnel).
options.B: Is limited to State actors and State parties to armed conflicts only, with no similar obligation applicable to armed opposition groups.
options.C: Is not at all applicable to armed opposition groups, as no practice has yet been identified with respect to their encouragement towards teaching of IHL to the civilian population under their control.
options.D: Is only applicable in international armed conflicts.

question: Under IHL, is ensuring respect for IHL an erga omnes obligation?

options.A: No. The obligation to respect and ensure respect for IHL is exclusive to the parties to the conflict, as IHL regulates their behaviour during the duration of the armed conflict only, be it international or non-international.
options.B: No. States have no means to influence or control the behaviour of the parties to an armed conflict if their armed forces are not directly involved.
options.C: Yes. The obligation to ensure respect is not limited to the behaviour of parties to an armed conflict, but includes the requirement that States do everything in their power to ensure that IHL is respected universally.
options.D: Yes. State practice establishes this rule as a customary norm applicable in both international and non-international armed conflicts. International and regional organizations as well as international conferences support that States must call for respect of IHL even if they are not themselves directly involved in an armed conflict.

question: Which of the following statements accurately reflects the position of IHL on the role of third States ensuring respect for IHL?

options.A: The obligation of third States to ensure respect for IHL is based on the principle of reciprocity. All States must respect and ensure respect for IHL because they may one day be the subject of its application should they be involved in an armed conflict, and, therefore, expect the IHL rules to be respected during the hostilities.
options.B: The obligation of third States to ensure respect for IHL is limited to implementing what is provided for in common Article 1 of the Geneva Conventions and Article 1(1) of Additional Protocol I.
options.C: There is agreement that all States have a right to require respect for IHL by parties to any conflict. According to case law, IHL norms are erga omnes and, therefore, all States have a legal interest in their observance and consequently a legal entitlement to demand their respect.
options.D: None of the above.

question: According to IHL, how may States lawfully put pressure on parties to an armed conflict to respect IHL?

options.A: States may make objections to violations of IHL, for instance, through bilateral diplomatic protests, in international fora or by means of resolutions of international organizations.
options.B: Under IHL, States are empowered to use force in cases of a perceived violation of IHL, especially of serious violations, as reflected both in Additional Protocol I of the Geneva Conventions and UN Charter.
options.C: By implementing their obligations to establish universal jurisdiction over grave breaches, to investigate war crimes falling within their jurisdiction, and to prosecute the suspects if appropriate States can ensure respect for IHL.
options.D: Collective measures by States to try to ensure respect have taken the form of holding international conferences on specific situations, investigating possible violations, creating ad hoc criminal tribunals and courts, imposing international sanctions and sending of peacekeeping or peace-enforcement troops.

question: According to IHL, which of the following statements is NOT a condition for lawful belligerent reprisals?

options.A: Reprisals may only be taken in reaction to a prior serious violation of IHL, and only for the purpose of inducing the adversary to comply with the law.
options.B: Reprisals may only be carried out as a measure of last resort, when no other lawful measures are available to induce the adversary to respect the law.
options.C: The decision to resort to reprisals must be taken at the highest political or military level and may not be decided by local commanders.
options.D: Belligerent reprisals may be taken as a reaction to serious violations of international law of any type, as reprisals are aimed at inducing the adversary to comply with the law.

question: Why are States reluctant to resort to belligerent reprisals in armed conflicts?

options.A: Many military manuals see reprisals as an excuse for illegal methods of warfare that carry a danger of escalation through repeated reprisals and counter reprisals.
options.B: Reprisals are ineffective as a means of enforcement, in particular because reprisals risk leading to an escalation of violations.
options.C: Reprisals offer limited military advantage/ gain when compared to other methods.
options.D: The categories of persons and objects that can be subjected to reprisal action have been reduced, and reprisal action against certain persons and objects that were often the target for reprisals are now prohibited under customary international law.

question: Does IHL prohibit reprisals against the civilian population?

options.A: As long as the principle of proportionality is respected, civilian populations, or individual members thereof, may be the object of reprisals.
options.B: Yes, article 51(6) of Additional Protocol I prohibits attacks against the civilian population or civilians by way of reprisals.
options.C: There is a trend in favour of prohibiting reprisals against civilians during the conduct of hostilities, however there is no crystallyzed customary law rule on account of existing contrary State practice.
options.D: Only prisoners of war and military objectives may be the target of reprisals.

question: Under IHL:

options.A: Reprisals are prohibited against the property of protected persons.
options.B: The natural environment and works and installations containing dangerous forces are protected from attacks directed by way of reprisals in all situations.
options.C: Cultural property of great importance to the cultural heritage of a people is protected from reprisals, including historic monuments, works of art and places of worship.
options.D: Reprisals against civilian objects are always prohibited during the conduct of hostilities.

question: Does  IHL prohibit reprisals in non-international armed conflicts?

options.A: Generally yes, however similar to the customary law rule applicable to international armed conflicts, when reprisals are not prohibited under international law, they may be used in non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: No, as the purpose of reprisals, and conditions to resort to reprisals, refer to inter-State relations. There is no practice of reprisals in situations of non-international armed conflicts or the use of reprisals by non-state armed groups.
options.C: Yes, however since all practice describing the purpose of reprisals and conditions for resort to them refers to inter-State relations, in non-international armed conflicts the prohibition only applies to non-state actors.
options.D: Yes, reprisals in non-international armed conflicts are prohibited, along with other countermeasures against persons who do not or who have ceased to take a direct part in hostilities.

question: What does IHL say about reprisals against protected objects?

options.A: There is no prohibition of reprisals against some specific protected objects, such as medical objects, including buildings, vessels and equipment.
options.B: Reprisals against protected objects are prohibited, although cultural property and heritage are not considered protected objects.
options.C: Reprisals against protected objects are permissible where the following conditions are met: they are taken in reaction to a prior serious violation of IHL, they are used as a measure of last resort, they are proportionate to the violation they aim to stop, the decision to resort to reprisals is taken at the highest level of government and the resprisal actions stop as soon as the adversary complies with the law.
options.D: Reprisals against objects protected under the Geneva Conventions and Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property are prohibited.

question: When is a State responsible for violations of IHL?

options.A: States are responsible for violations committed by private persons or groups that claim to act on their behalf even if the States do not acknowledge or adopt these violations as their own conduct.
options.B: States are responsible for violations committed by members of a its armed forces or for violations committed by persons or groups acting on its instruction, or under its direction or control.
options.C: A State is responsible for the omissions of its organs when they are under a duty to act, such as in the case of commanders and other superiors who are responsible for preventing and punishing war crimes.
options.D: States are responsible for the acts of private firms or individuals that are used by their armed forces to accomplish tasks that are typically those of the armed forces.

question: Is a State responsible for violations of IHL committed through acts that went against its instructions?

options.A: A State is only be responsible for violations committed by persons or groups that are acting in accordance with the State's official instructions.
options.B: A State is responsible for all acts committed by its organs and other persons or entities empowered to act on its behalf, even if such organs or persons exceed their authority or contravene instructions.
options.C: A State is reponsible for all acts committed by its organs however violations committed by persons or groups previously empowered to act upon the State's behalf which acts contravene the State's instructions cannot be attributable to that State.
options.D: None of the above.

question: According to IHL:

options.A: Armed opposition groups incur responsibility for acts committed by persons forming part of such groups, but the consequences of such responsibility are not clear.
options.B: State responsibility cannot be retroactive, in the sense that acts committed by private individuals or groups later acknowledged and adopted by the State are not attributable to it.
options.C: A State may be held responsible for the actions of persons or groups which are neither its organs nor entitled, under national law, to exercise governmental authority, if they act on the instructions of, or under the direction or control of, that State.
options.D: The conduct of a single private individual or a group that is not militarily organized is attributable to the State only if specific instructions concerning that conduct are given.

question: How are denials of quarter addressed under IHL?

options.A: A denial of quarter is prohibited and adversary forces must be given an opportunity to surrender and to be taken prisoner.
options.B: In some situations, IHL permits the denial of quarter for instance in specific cases of self-preservation.
options.C: Military operations can be conducted on the basis that no quarter shall be given.
options.D: IHL prohibits the acts of giving the order that there shall be no survivors, threatening adversaries with this and conducting hostilities on this basis.

question: Are there situations that can support a "no quarter" order in an armed conflict?

options.A: Yes, if enemies are captured under unusual conditions of combat which prevent their evacuation.
options.B: No, IHL does not provided any exception to the prohibition of denial of quarter.
options.C: Yes, if the commander perceives the actions prior to the person's capture as wrong or illegal.
options.D: Yes, but this is dependent on the role, function, unit or legal status of the person captured.

question: Is the prohibition on denial of quarter applicable in all armed conflicts?

options.A: No, only in international armed conflicts and only to States since non-state armed groups are likely to face practical challenges in providing for detention.
options.B: No, only in non-international armed conflicts.
options.C: Yes, the prohibition, being part of customary international law, applies to both international and non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: It depends on the domestic legislation of each State.

question: Under what circumstances can a person be recognized as hors de combat in an armed conflict?

options.A: They have to be in the power of an adverse party, provided that they abstain from any hostile act and do not attempt to escape.
options.B: They have to be medical or religious personnel, provided that they abstain from any hostile act and do not attempt to escape.
options.C: They have to be defenceless due to unconsciousness, shipwreck, wounds or sickness, provided that they abstain from any hostile act and do not attempt to escape.
options.D: They have to clearly indicate their intention to surrender, provided that they abstain from any hostile act and do not attempt to escape.

question: According to IHL, what are the obligations regarding the treatment of persons hors de combat?

options.A: They must be treated humanely.
options.B: They must not be attacked, unless keeping them as prisoners or evacuating them proves to be exceedingly difficult.
options.C: They must be protected from harm, such as cruel treatment, violence to life and person, murder, torture and mutilation.
options.D: They have the right to receive quarter.

question: What actions can lead a person hors de combat to lose their protection under IHL?

options.A: Refusal to give military information by the persons hors de combat.
options.B: Any hostile acts by the person hors de combat.
options.C: Attempt to escape by the person hors de combat.
options.D: Authorization by the military commander on the loss of protection, if considered necessary for gaining a strategic advantage over the adversary.

question: Two soldiers from State X who are carrying a wounded soldier are retreating to their own lines while under attack from soldiers from State Y. Is the continued attack from State Y's soldiers a violation of IHL?

options.A: Yes, according to IHL, retreating soldiers, who are considered hors de combat, may not be attacked.
options.B: As long as the attack against State X's soldiers is not directed towards the wounded soldier and precautionary measures are taken to avoid incidental effects from that attack upon the wounded soldier, there is no violation of IHL.
options.C: No, State Y's soldiers may continue to attack State X's unwounded soldiers until they are rendered hors de combat.
options.D: Yes, although IHL does not prohibit attacks on retreating soldiers, the presence of a wounded soldier confers protection from attack on the two unwounded soldiers carrying him.

question: Which of the following actions would not comply with the IHL prohibition against attacking persons parachuting from an aircraft?

options.A: Targeting persons parachuting from aircraft in distress during their descent.
options.B: Targeting troops involved in a military operation while they are airborne.
options.C: Targeting persons parachuting from aircraft in distress if they are engaging in clearly hostile acts.
options.D: All of the above.

question: Can parties to an armed conflict seize military equipment belonging to an adverse party?

options.A: Yes, all movable State property located on the battlefield may be appropriated as war booty.
options.B: Yes, private items can be taken, even if they are not being used in hostilities.
options.C: Yes, private property used for hostile purposes, found on the battlefield or combat zone, may be appropriated.
options.D: Yes, but this does not include arms and ammunition.

question: Under IHL, what rules apply to the war booty of medical units?

options.A: If appropriated, mobile medical units must be reserved for the care of the sick and wounded.
options.B: Both mobile and fixed medical units can be used for whatever purposes, with no specific regard for the sick and wounded.
options.C: IHL does not differentiate between mobile and fixed medical units.
options.D: The intended purpose of the fixed medical units may not be diverted as long as they are required for the care of the wounded and sick.

question: According to customary IHL, under what circumstances is the seizure of an adversary's property not prohibited?

options.A: When the commander during a military operation, or person of higher rank, deems such action proportionate to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.
options.B: When imperative military necessity so requires.
options.C: Enemy property can never be confiscated or seized.
options.D: When the property belongs to the State armed forces.

question: Can parties to an armed conflict destroy the property of an adversary in a military operation?

options.A: Yes, the destruction is lawful but only when rendered absolutely necessary by military operations.
options.B: Yes, but only if imperative military necessity so requires, because IHL prohibits wanton and unlawful destruction.
options.C: No, property must be protected from destruction in all circumstances.
options.D: Yes, both the movable and immovable property of an adversary may be destroyed in any situation since, on account of their ownership by the enemy, they are automatically considered military objectives.

question: Under IHL, can private property in occupied territory ever be confiscated or destroyed?

options.A: Private property may be confiscated, provided that under no circumstances may the property be destroyed or its nature changed.
options.B: A State may demand the temporary or permanent use of movable or immovable private property, if compensation is paid.
options.C: IHL does not regulate confiscation of private property under occupation, as this is a matter regulated by domestic legislation only.
options.D: In occupied territory, the seizure of private property is permissible only in cases of imperative military necessity.

question: In cases of occupation and according to IHL, what rules must an occupying power comply with regarding public property?

options.A: Movable public property that can be used for military operations may be confiscated.
options.B: All movable and immovable public property may be confiscated, including the property of the occupying power which is dedicated to religion, charity, education, the arts, and sciences.
options.C: The occupying power must administer immovable public property according to the rule of usufruct.
options.D: IHL permits the seizure and destruction of public property, both movable and immovable, as long as wanton and unlawful damage and destruction is avoided.

question: Which of the following acts amount to pillage under IHL?

options.A: Taking, for private use, the arms and ammunition of wounded and sick persons who are found on the battlefield.
options.B: Only cases of organised rather than individual acts of appropriating property without the owner’s consent.
options.C: The extraction of valuable minerals, such as gold, coltan and diamonds, by an armed group over territory it controls to fund military operations.
options.D: Seizure by an occupying power of food, valuables and livestock from the civilian population.

question: Under IHL, what kinds of property may not be pillaged?

options.A: Movable property belonging to civilians, wounded, sick or shipwrecked persons, prisoners of war or the dead on the battlefield.
options.B: No objects fall under this category as all property is subject to acquisition and destruction in armed conflict.
options.C: Public property in occupied territory belonging to the enemy State or movable private property of protected persons appropriated without the owner's consent.
options.D: Movable and immovable property belonging to civilians, wounded, sick or shipwrecked persons, prisoners of war or the dead on the battlefield.

question: Can parties to an armed conflict ever use starvation as a method of warfare?

options.A: Yes, starvation of the civilian population can be used as a method of warfare, because it leads to faster military gains and can respect the principle of proportionality.
options.B: No, and as a consequence of this prohibition, a naval blockade may never be used, even if it helps a military objective, since the starvation of the civilian population is a foreseeable consequence.
options.C: No, and in fact, sieges that have the deliberate purpose of directly starving the civilian population in the besieged area are prohibited.
options.D: None of the above.

question: Under IHL, may a city under the control of insurgents but populated by civilians be subjected to a naval blockade that leads to starvation?

options.A: Yes, IHL does not prohibit naval blockades that cause starvation as long as they are not intended to starve the civilian population.
options.B: Yes, civilians and combatants may be adversely affected by the blockade.
options.C: Naval blockades that cause starvation are only lawful if the blockading party allows the free passage of humanitarian relief to meet the needs of the inadequately provided for cvilian population.
options.D: Naval blockades that aim to achieve military objectives are permitted, including in cases where the passage of humanitarian relief for a civilian population in need is not allowed by the blockading party.

question: What IHL rules apply to objects indispensable to the survival of the civilian population?

options.A: These objects may not be attacked, destroyed, removed or rendered useless.
options.B: As the protection afforded to these objects is absolute, there are no exceptions in which they may be attacked or destroyed.
options.C: Objects being used solely for the sustenance of combatants qualify as military objectives and may be attacked.
options.D: They may be attacked if the aim is to force the migration of the civilians, leading them away from the conflict area.

question: When is the use of 'scorched earth policy' not prohibited under IHL?

options.A: When carried out  by a party to an international armed conflict in defence of national territory under its control against invasion and where required by imperative military necessity.
options.B: Customary IHL does not accomodate the "scorched earth policy" as it would result in unnecessary suffering amongst the civilian population.
options.C: Customary IHL permits the destruction of agricultural areas, irrigation works and crops in support of a military action.
options.D: When carried out  by an armed group in defence of territory under its control against invasion and where required by imperative military necessity.

question: Under customary IHL, what are the conditions for granting humanitarian relief for civilians in need?

options.A: The humanitarian efforts must be controlled by the parties to the conflict.
options.B: Humanitarian relief must be impartial in character.
options.C: Humanitarian relief must be conducted without any adverse distinction.
options.D: The relief supplies and consignments must be supervised for the safety of all parties, which may result in the impediment of assistance.

question: Which parties or organizations are authorized to provide humanitarian relief for populations in need, according to customary IHL?

options.A: Neighbouring States may cooperate in providing humanitarian assistance.
options.B: International organizations and neutral States may offer humanitarian assistance, even if the actions are not conducted impartially.
options.C: Humanitarian organizations may provide impartial humanitarian relief.
options.D: Third States, which are not parties to the conflict, may facilitate or cooperate with humanitarian efforts.

question: What are the obligations of the parties to the conflict regarding humanitarian relief personnel, under customary IHL?

options.A: They must grant the free and unimpeded passage, ensuring the freedom of movement, of any organization providing relief, even if not duly authorized.
options.B: They must ensure freedom of movement of authorized humanitarian relief personnel, which is essential to the exercise of their functions.
options.C: Under costumary IHL, the parties must adopt regulations on the passage of relief, such as search and distribution measures.
options.D: According to costumary IHL, the parties must allow the distribution of assistance only under the supervision of a Protecting Power.

question: In what circumstances may the freedom of movement granted to humanitarian relief personnel be limited under IHL?

options.A: The freedom of movement of humanitarian relief personnel may never be limited.
options.B: In two situations: if the safety of relief personnel is endangered and if justified by military necessity, with no limitions on duration.
options.C: In case of imperative military necessity, for a limited duration only. This is justified on the basis that relief operations must not be allowed to interfere with military operations, lest the safety of humanitarian relief personnel be endangered.
options.D: If the area is deemed unsafe due to the presence of mines, booby-traps and other devices, in which case the freedom of movement may be restricted indefinitely.

question: Are ruses of war prohibited under IHL?

options.A: Rruses of war are prohibited  because they necessarily violate IHL obligations.
options.B: Ruses of war are considered lawful if they adhere to IHL.
options.C: Ruses of war, such as feigning attacks, retreats or flights may be used, but laying dummy mines or making use of the enermy's signal, are prohibited.
options.D: Ruses, such as pretending to communicate with troops, moving landmarks and simulations are not prohibited, if they do not violate IHL.

question: Rebel forces have secured the northern part of State A. Two villages on the new border between State A and the rebels are being terrorized and used as a jump-off point for rebel operations against State A's forces. What options are open to State A's military commander under IHL?

options.A: For their own safety, the commander can order the civilians to evacuate themselves from the villages and although there is no obligation to assist them in this, the troops should offer to assist them.
options.B: The commander can evacuate the civilians from the border areas since IHL allows a party to the conflict to displace civilians for their own security or for reasons of imperative military necessity.
options.C: The commander can engage in military operations against the rebel forces as long as they respect the principles of distinction, proportionality and precautions.
options.D: The commander can evacuate the civilians from the border areas and can do so until the end of active hostilities, even if the rebel forces cease their presence by this border before then.

question: What protection does IHL offer to medical personnel as such?

options.A: Medical personnel exclusively assigned to medical duties temporarily are entitled to respect and protection against attack as medical personnel for the duration of their assignment, after which they are protected as civilians.
options.B: Only military medical personnel permanently asigned to medical duties must be respected and protected in all circumstances.
options.C: Both civilian and military medical personnel exclusively asigned to medical duties must be respected and protected in all circumstances.
options.D: Medical personnel are not the object of specific protection under IHL.

question: How do medical personnel lose their special protection under IHL?

options.A: If they resist or hinder the enemy's attempt to take control of a medical unit.
options.B: If they care for enemy wounded or use small arms to protect themselves or their patients.
options.C: If they commit, outside their humanitarian function, acts harmful to the enemy.
options.D: If they commit hostile acts, outside of their humanitarian function.

question: Can a party to an armed conflict punish a person for disobeying an order to perform an act that would be contrary to medical ethics?

options.A: Yes, in cases where the refusal to perform this act would significantly hinder military operations.
options.B: No, persons engaged in medical activities may not be compelled to engage in activities that violate medical ethics.
options.C: No, it is prohibited to compell any person engaged in medical activities to conduct medical or scientific experiments not indicated by his or her patient's state of health and inconsistent with generally accepted medical standards.
options.D: No, it is prohibited to puinsh a person for performing medical duties compatible with medical ethics.

question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the position of IHL on medical secrecy?

options.A: IHL allows for a person engaged in medical activities who performs an urgent surgery on an enemy prisoner of war to be punished for refusing to divulge the patient's information as prescribed by national law.
options.B: IHL prohibits medical personnel from withholding medical information contained in a medical file.
options.C: IHL prohibits States from obliging medical personnel to provide information concerning communicable diseases found on enemy patients.
options.D: There is no rule in international law which prohibits States from adopting legislation making it compulsory for medical personnel to withhold or divulge the information of their patients.

question: How does IHL protect religious personnel?

options.A: IHL protects all religious personnel as cvilians. There is no special protection under IHL.
options.B: IHL only offers special protection to military religious personnel which protection is the same as that afforded to medical personnel.
options.C: IHL protects civilian and military religious personnel exclusively assigned to religious duties in all circumstances.
options.D: Customary IHL protects civilian and military religious personnel exclusively assigned to religious duties in international armed conflicts only.

question: Which of the following statements concerning religious personnel is correct under IHL?

options.A: Religious personnel lose their protection for carrying light individual weapons.
options.B: Religious personnel engaged simultaneously in religious duties and non-religious military functions are entitled to protection and respect as religious personnel.
options.C: Religious personnel exclusively assigned to religious duties are protected entitled to protection and respect as religious personnel.
options.D: Religious personnel enjoy the same privileges as permanent medical personnel.

question: How does IHL protect medical units?

options.A: IHL provides that medical units exclusively assigned to medical purposes must be respected and protected in all circumstances.
options.B: IHL does not protect medical units, only medical personnel.
options.C: IHL only affords specific protection to medical units in international armed conflicts.
options.D: Medical units may use the distinctive emblems of the Geneva Conventions in conformity with international law.

question: How does IHL define medical units?

options.A: The term “medical units” refers to establishments and other units, whether military or civilian, organized for medical purposes, be they fixed or mobile, permanent or temporary.
options.B: The term includes hospitals, preventive medicine centers and blood transfusion centers, but does not encompass medical depots and the medical and pharmaceutical stores of such units.
options.C: The term refers to medical establishments recognized and authorized by one of the parties with the right to display the distinctive emblems.
options.D: IHL does not define medical units.

question: In which of the following cases would a hospital lose its special protection under IHL?

options.A: The hospital is being used as a shelter for able-bodied combatants.
options.B: The presence of two wounded high-ranking officials from a NSAG in the hospital where they are being treated and which hospital is located in an area controlled by that armed group.
options.C: The hospital fails to display the distinctive emblems.
options.D: The hospital is being used as an observation post to transmit information of military value.

question: Which of the following statements concerning medical transports is true accrording to IHL?

options.A: Attacks on medical aircraft, when they are recognized as such, are only prohibited when there is a special agreement governing the flight and the route has been previously agreed upon.
options.B: IHL does not protect civilian medical transports.
options.C: IHL does not protect temporary medical transports.
options.D: None of the above.

question: When do medical trasports lose protection as such under IHL?

options.A: Medical transports are always protected under IHL without exception.
options.B: If they transport the wounded and sick without previous communication to the enemy.
options.C: If they transport healthy troops.
options.D: If they collect military intelligence whilst performing medical duties.

question: How does IHL address the display of the distinctive emblems?

options.A: IHL is mostly silent as the matter is not regulated.
options.B: IHL allows attacks on medical or religious personnel and objects for failure to wear or display the distinctive emblems.
options.C: IHL confers automatic protected status to objects and personnel displaying the distinctive emblems.
options.D: None of the above.

question: Does IHL protect humanitarian relief personnel?

options.A: Only humanitarian relief personnel wearing the distinctive emblems are protected under IHL.
options.B: Humanitarian relief personnel are not protected under  IHL.
options.C: Yes, humanitarian relief personnel must be respected and protected as such against attack.
options.D: None of the above.

question: How does IHL protect humanitarian relief personnel?

options.A: IHL enjoins parties to a conflict to ensure the safety of humanitarian relief personnel.
options.B: According to customary IHL, humanitarian relief personnel are only entitled to protection as such where their presence has been authorized.
options.C: Under IHL, humanitarian relief personnel are entitled to protection against attack, harassment, intimidation and arbitrary detention.
options.D: IHL protects humanitarian relief personnel against risks associated with the performance of their tasks.

question: How does IHL protect humanitarian relief objects?

options.A: IHL does not protect objects used for humanitarian relief operations, only humanitarian relief personnel.
options.B: IHL protects installations, material, units and vehicles employed in a humanitarian relief operation against attack.
options.C: IHL protects humanitarian relief objects in both international and non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: The destruction, misappropriation or looting of humanitarian relief objects is prohibited by IHL.

question: Under what conditions does IHL protect personnel and objects involved in a peacekeeping mission?

options.A: Personnel and objects involved in peacekeeping and peace enforcement missions in accordance with the UN Charter are protected from attack as long as they are not taking direct part in hostilities.
options.B: Only objects involved in a peacekeeping mission are protected under IHL, as they are considered civilian objects.
options.C: Personnel and objects involved in a peacekeeping mission in accordance with the UN Charter are protected from attacks by IHL as long as they are entitled to he protection given to civililans and civilian objects and as long as the peacekeepers are not taking a direct part in hostilities.
options.D: Personnel and objects involved in a peacekeeping mission are only protected by IHL in international armed conflicts.

question: How does IHL protect journalists?

options.A: IHL only protects journalists and war correspondents in international armed conflicts.
options.B: Journalists are only protected by IHL against attacks where they are properly identified as such and distinguish themselves from civilians.
options.C: Journalists are protected against attacks as civilians unless and for such time as they take a direct part in hostilities.
options.D: Civilian journalists and war correspondents are entitled to prisoner of war status if captured.

question: What is the difference between a civilian journalist and a war correspondent under IHL?

options.A: War correspondents have special authorization to accompany the armed forces of a State without being members thereof. Furthermore, they are entitled to prisoner-of-war status upon capture. By comparison, civilian journalists are independent of the armed forces of a party to the conflict and not entitled to prisoner of war status upon capture.
options.B: There are no significant differences between a civilian journalist and a war correspondent under customary IHL.
options.C: In both international and non-international armed conflicts, civilian journalists become war correspondents upon receiving authorization by the enemy party, and are entitled prisoner-of-war status if captured.
options.D: War correspondent are exclusively assigned to journalistic duties and, thus, are entitled to prisoner of war status upon capture. Civilian journalists are not exclusively assigned to such duties and, thus, are not afforded protection as such.

question: What conditions must be met for a hospital zone to enjoy protection as a protected area under IHL?

options.A: Hospital zones must be recognized by an agreement with the adverse party.
options.B: Persons whose normal permanent residence is within these zones must be relocated to make room for authorised beneficiaries.
options.C: The zone must not provide shelter to combatants or serve any military purpose.
options.D: Hospital zones must not contain military objectives but they may be defended militarily.

question: What is a neutralized zone’s primary purpose in an armed conflict?

options.A: Providing a temporary ceasefire area for negotiations between parties of an armed conflict.
options.B: Creating a space where military and civilian personnel can rest during hostilities.
options.C: Protecting, without distinction, wounded and sick combatants or non-combatants and civilians who take no part in hostilities and who, while they reside in the zones, perform no work of a military character.
options.D: Establishing a base for neutral humanitarian organizations to conduct relief operations.

question: What actions concerning demilitarised zones are prohibited under IHL?

options.A: Allowing military personnel to use the zones as weapons storage facilities.
options.B: Authorising the presence of peacekeeping forces or police personnel to maintain law and order.
options.C: Occupation of the zones by any party to the conflict.
options.D: Permitting troop movements within the zones.

question: What actions can lead a demilitarized zone to lose its protection as such under IHL?

options.A: The authorities or population within the zone commit acts of hostility.
options.B: The zone is used as a temporary shelter by retreating combatants who do not engage in hostilities while inside the zone.
options.C: Any breach of the agreement establishing the zone.
options.D: A party to the conflict conducting reconnaissance flights over the demilitarized zone, even as an agreed method of supervision.

question: Under IHL, what conditions make a town or locality non-defended?

options.A: The town has been evacuated of all civilians to ensure it remains uninhabited.
options.B: All combatants, as well as mobile weapons and mobile military equipment, have been evacuated
options.C: The town is situated far from the frontlines of combat and be clearly marked as an open town.
options.D: No hostile use is made of fixed military installations or establishments.

question: What primary legal consequence flows from the declaration of a locality as non-defended under IHL?

options.A: The town cannot be attacked because there is no military necessity to attack a town that is open for occupation.
options.B: Civilians from a non-defended town may not resist an ensuing occupation.
options.C: Parties to the conflict may not conduct military operations in or occupy non-defended localities.
options.D: The town is required to provide shelter and resources to military personnel from opposing forces.

question: Under IHL, which of the following statements accurately reflects the protection afforded to cultural property during armed conflict?

options.A: Cultural property of great importance to the cultural heritage of a people may always be attacked if it is deemed to be of strategic military importance.
options.B: Parties to the conflict are required to take special care to protect cultural property from damage and destruction in military operations unless they are military objectives.
options.C: Cultural property is only protected if it is officially listed by an international organization such as UNESCO.
options.D: Cultural property may not be used for military purposes even if it is not being actively used by civilians.

question: Which of the following actions would constitute a violation of the protection afforded to cultural property under IHL?

options.A: Conducting military operations in the vicinity of cultural property without taking precautions to avoid damage.
options.B: Temporarily relocating cultural artifacts to a safer location during an armed conflict.
options.C: Using a cultural site for humanitarian aid distribution while ensuring the site remains undamaged.
options.D: Designating cultural property as a protected site in accordance with national laws.

question: Under what circumstances does customary IHL allow for the use of property of great importance to the cultural heritage of every people for purposes which are likely to expose it to destruction or damage?

options.A: When the property is not actively being used for cultural activities.
options.B: If the property can be restored after military use, thereby minimizing damage.
options.C: Only when it is deemed imperative by military necessity.
options.D: When a temporary ceasefire is in place, allowing for military use without risk of immediate hostilities.

question: Which of the following actions do not constitute a violation of customary IHL in relation to the protection of cultural property of great importance to the cultural heritage of peoples?

options.A: Conducting military operations in a historic district ensuring that cultural heritage sites are not used for military purposes and that precautions are being taken to protect the sites from damage.
options.B: Authorizing the use of a cultural site as a command post for military efforts due to a lack of alternative locations that offer a similar military advantage.
options.C: Evacuating cultural artifacts from a threatened museum to protect them from imminent destruction.
options.D: Temporarily using a cultural site as a medical facility if there is an urgent need for medical assistance.

question: What does the obligation to respect cultural property entail for parties to an armed conflict?

options.A: Parties to a conflict should use cultural properties for military operations if deemed necessary for their strategic advantage.
options.B: Parties to a conflict are required to proctect cultural property from any form of theft, pillage, misappropriation, and any acts of vandalism.
options.C: Parties to an armed conflict may not seize, destroy or wilfully damage institutions dedicated to religion, charity, education, the arts and sciences, historic monuments, works of art and science.
options.D: Parties to a conflict are obliged to document and catalog cultural property.

question: Which of the following statements do not accurately reflect the protection afforded to cultural property under customary IHL during armed conflict?

options.A: While the destruction of cultural property is prohibited, it is not illegal to vandalize it to affect the other party to the conflict.
options.B: Only the defender, specifically an officer at a certain level of command within that Party, and not the attacker may waive the special protection granted to cultural property.
options.C: Only religious and educational institutions are specially protected, while historical monuments and works of art can be damaged if necessary.
options.D: Under customary IHL, cultural property enjoys special protection in international armed conflicts but not under non-international armed conflicts.

question: According to IHL, what obligations does an occupying power have in relation to cultural property in occupied territory?

options.A: The occupying power must export cultural property from the occupied territory if it is for safekeeping during the conflict.
options.B: The occupying power is responsible for preventing the illicit export of cultural property and, if exported, ensuring its return to the competent authorities of the occupied territory.
options.C: The occupying power must return cultural property only after the conflict has ended and a peace agreement has been reached to ensure its safety.
options.D: The occupying power can auction off any cultural property found in the occupied territory to prevent illicit activities.

question: According to IHL, what should an occupying power do if cultural property has been illegally removed from the occupied territory?

options.A: The occupying power should keep the cultural property until an international court decides on its rightful ownership.
options.B: The occupying power must ensure that the cultural property is returned to the competent authorities of the occupied territory.
options.C: The occupying power has no obligation in this regard as the property has been removed from the territory under their control.
options.D: The occupying power is only required to document the removal of cultural property, not to take further action.

question: When are attacks against works and installations containing dangerous forces not prohibited under IHL?

options.A: When they are used for military purposes, regardless of potential consequences for civilians.
options.B: When particular care is taken to avoid the release of dangerous forces and consequent severe losses among the civilian population.
options.C: Attacks are prohibited under all circumstances, even if they are used for military purposes.
options.D: In the same way for any other military objective, when the release of dangerous forces by an attacking party from an attack would not cause loss of civilian life or harm to the environment that is excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage.

question: Under IHL, which of the following measures must be taken in relation to installations that contain dangerous forces?

options.A: Parties to a conflict must ensure that attacks are conducted at night to minimize the exposure of civilians.
options.B: Parties to a conflict must avoid situating military objectives at or in the vicinity of such works and installations.
options.C: Parties to a conflict must take all feasible precautions, including by not using works and installations containing dangerous forces in direct support of military action and by never using them to shield military operations.
options.D: Where possible, parties to a conflict must maximize the immediate destruction of the target installation, through, for instance, the use of explosives.

question: Under what circumstances may the natural environment be attacked during armed conflict?

options.A: The natural environment may be attacked, and in fact destroyed, if so required by imperative military necessity.
options.B: Any part of the natural environment can be destroyed if it is located near a military objective.
options.C: The natural environment may only be attacked if it constitutes a military objective.
options.D: Attacks on the natural environment are allowed as long as they result in a tactical advantage, even if they cause excessive damage.

question: When are attacks against the natural environment prohibited in an armed conflict?

options.A: When the attacks constitute reprisals.
options.B: Where there is a reasonable expectation that the enemy will suffer heavy casualties as a result.
options.C: The natural environment may never be the object of attack as it is incapable of becoming a military objective.
options.D: When the incidental environmental damage is excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.

question: What are parties to an armed conflict required to do, concerning the natural environment, during military operations?

options.A: Parties may disregard environmental considerations if there is no clear evidence that their actions will cause significant damage.
options.B: Parties must take all feasible precautions to avoid, and in any event to minimize, incidental damage to the environment during military operations.
options.C: Environmental protection is not a priority in military operations if it interferes with achieving military objectives.
options.D: Choose lawful methods and means of warfare as all methods and means of warfare may not be used freely without due regard to the potential environmental impact caused by such use.

question: How does IHL address situations where there is uncertainty about the environmental impact of military operations?

options.A: If there is scientific uncertainty about the potential environmental damage, parties to the conflict are not obliged to take feasible precautions.
options.B: Uncertainty about the effects of military operations on the environment allows parties to proceed with their plans reduces a party's obligations to take precautions.
options.C: Lack of scientific certainty does not absolve a party from taking precautions to protect the natural environment.
options.D: Precautions to protect the environment are required at all times.

question: How does customary IHL regulate the use of methods or means of warfare when it comes to the protection of the natural environment?

options.A: The use of any weapons that may cause short-term environmental damage is not ptohibited as long as the military objective is achieved.
options.B: Methods or means of warfare intended to cause widespread, long-term, and severe damage to the natural environment are prohibited.
options.C: The willful destruction of the natural environment is prohibited even if it results in military advantage.
options.D: Any damage to the natural environment is acceptable if it does not cause excessive destruction.

question: According to customary IHL, how should the natural environment be treated in the context of armed conflicts?

options.A: The destruction of the natural environment may not be used as a weapon even if it serves a strategic purpose in military operations.
options.B: Destruction of the natural environment may not be employed as a tactic to weaken the enemy's resources.
options.C: The use of methods that intentionally cause severe environmental damage is acceptable if it is part of a broader military strategy.

options.B: Unnecessary suffering is a harm beyond that which is necessary to incapacitate enemy combatants from fighting, or harm which renders their deaths inevitable when they could have been otherwise incapacitated from fighting.
options.C: Unnecessary suffering refers exclusively to the suffering of civilians, since they are not legitimate military targets.
options.D: Unnecessary suffering refers to any harm caused by the aggressor during war, in accordance with the United Nations' stated goal of maintaining international peace.

options.A: It is unlawful to apply physical or mental coercion to protected civilians to obtain information from them. Just the threat of shooting the civilians who do not comply is a violation of IHL.
options.B: Since the soldiers managed to round up all the civilians, the perpetrator is definitely among them. The commander can threaten to punish all of them if they do not identify the perpetrator and carry out his threat since collective punishment is not a  violation of IHL.
options.C:
The platoon commander may execute the most likely suspects in retaliation and if the group refuses to divulge the identity of the perpetrator since reprisals against civilians and their property in occupied

options.D: The platoon commander may  put in place preventative administrative measures to protect his platoon, such as curfews, as they carry out further investigations including non-coercive interrogations of the civilians.

question: Under  IHL, during which situations may biological weapons be used?

options.A: In any forms of armed conflict, both international and non-international, without restrictions.

options.A: They may be possessed, but not used.

question: During which situations may chemical weapons be used in the context of an armed conflict?

options.A: In any types of conflict, both international and non-international, without restrictions.

options.C: Only in international armed conflicts.

options.A: If they are aimed at vegetation that is not a military objective or otherwise may be expected to cause injury to civilians that is excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.

options.C: If they would cause widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment.
options.D: If they would fall under the prohibition of the use of biological weapons.

options.A: The principle of distinction.

options.A: They are more efficient at taking out whole groups of people at once, hence, they are used in crowd control situations.

options.D: They are cheaper to make than other types of munitions.

question: How should parties to an armed conflict apply the principle of distinction between civilians and combatants?

options.A: In some situations, parties to an armed conflict must distinguish between civilians and combatants.
options.B: Parties to an armed conflict must distinguish between civilians and combatants at all times.
options.C: Parties to an armed conflict may only direct attacks towards combatants. Civilians are protected against attacks, unless and for the duration in which they take direct part in hostilities.
options.D: In extreme circumstances, parties to an armed conflict can attack civilians if necessary for military necessity.

question: How does IHL prohibit the terrorizing of the civilian population?

options.A: Acts or threats of violence the primary purpose of which is to spread terror among the civilian population are prohibited.
