options.B: The prohibition of acts or threats of violence aimed at terrorizing the civilian population is not applicable in non-international armed conflicts.
options.C: Examples of acts of violence cited in practice as being prohibited under this rule can include offensive support or strike operations aimed at spreading terror among the civilian population, indiscriminate and widespread shelling, and the regular bombardment of cities, but also assault, rape, abuse and torture of women and children, and mass killing.
options.D: All of the above.

question: How are combatants defined under IHL?

options.A: All members of the armed forces of a party to the conflict are combatants, except medical and religious personnel.
options.B: In essence, a combatant is any person who, under responsible command, engages in hostile acts in an armed conflict on behalf of a party to the conflict.
options.C: All members of the armed forces of a party to the conflict are combatants, but only for the duration that they take part in hostilities.
options.D: All members of the armed forces of a party to the conflict, even large sections of the population that have been drafted but not incorporated into the armed forces, are considered combatants.

question: According to IHL, can armed forces have non-combatant members?

options.A: Any civilians accompanying the military are considered non-combatant members of the armed forces.
options.B: All persons affiliated with the party’s armed forces, even those without a combat function, and all civilians accompanying the military are considered combatants.
options.C: Military medical and religious personnel, while members of the armed forces, are considered non-combatants.
options.D: Persons who are members of the armed forces but do not have any combat function, such as judges, government officials, service providers, are considered non-combatants.

question: How are armed forces defined under IHL?

options.A: Armed forces of a party to the conflict consist of all organized armed groups which are under a command responsible to that party for the conduct of its subordinates.
options.B: Militia and volunteer corps are also considered part of the armed forces when they are under a command responsible to a party to the conflict.
options.C: Paramilitary, and armed law enforcement agencies such as police forces, gendarmerie, and constabulary are never incorporated into the armed forces.
options.D: There must be a distinction made between regular and irregular armed forces at all times.

question: How are civilians defined under IHL?

options.A: Members of armed opposition groups are considered civilians.
options.B: A civilian is any person who is not a member of the armed forces or of an organized armed group.
options.C: When inhabitants of a country which has not yet been occupied, spontaneously take up arms on the approach of the enemy as a levée en masse, these persons are also considered civilians.
options.D: Medical personnel of armed forces are also considered civilians.

question: To what extent do civilians enjoy protection from attack in an armed conflict?

options.A: Civilians are immune from direct attack unless and for such time as they take a direct part in hostilities.
options.B: Civilians enjoy protection from direct and incidental attacks at all times, even while taking a direct part in hostilities.
options.C: Civilians lose their protection for the duration that they take direct part in hostilities, in particular when they make use of weapons or other means to commit acts of violence against enemy forces or their material.
options.D: Civilians working in military objectives, such as munition factories, also lose their protection as they are now directly participating in hostilities.

question: How does the principle of distinction apply to civilian and military objectives in armed conflict?

options.A: The obligation of parties to the conflict to distinguish between civilian and military objectives has three components: to distinguish between civilian and military objectives at all times, permissibility of attacking military objectives, and the prohibition on any attacks on civilian objects.
options.B: The obligation to distinguish between civilian objects and military objectives and the prohibition on directing attacks against civilian objects does not apply in non-international armed conflicts.
options.C: The obligation to distinguish between civilian objects and military objectives prohibits direct attacks against civilian objects and does not deal with the question of incidental damage resulting from attacks directed against military objectives.
options.D: Intentionally directing attacks against civilian objects does not necessarily constitute a war crime in international armed conflicts.

question: How are military objectives defined in IHL?

options.A: Presence of civilians within or near military objectives renders such objectives immune from attack.
options.B: Military objectives are limited to those objects which by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose partial or total destruction, capture or neutralization, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage.
options.C: Dual-use facilities, such as civilian means of transportation and communication which can be used for military purposes are automatically considered military objectives.
options.D: Traditional examples of military objectives include establishments, buildings and positions where enemy combatants, their material and armaments are located, and military means of transportation and communication.

question: How are civilian objects defined according to IHL?

options.A: Civilian objects are objects that are not used for military purposes.
options.B: The definition of civilian objects has to be read together with the definition of military objectives: only those objects that qualify as military objectives may be attacked; other objects are protected against attack.
options.C: State practice considers civilian areas, towns, cities, villages, residential areas, dwellings, buildings and houses and schools, civilian means of transportation, hospitals, medical establishments and medical units, historic monuments, places of worship and cultural property, and the natural environment as prima facie civilian objects, provided they have not become military objectives in the final analysis.
options.D: Civilian objects are all objects that are not military objectives.

question: When do civilian objects lose protection from attack in an armed conflict?

options.A: Civilian objects lose their protection against attack until and for such time that they are military objectives.
options.B: Loss of protection of civilian objects must be read together with the basic rule that only military objectives may be attacked. It follows that when a civilian object is used in such a way that it loses its civilian character and qualifies as a military objective, it is liable to attack.
options.C: In case of doubt whether an object which is normally dedicated to civilian purposes, such as a place of worship or a school, is being used to make an effective contribution to military action, it can automatically be presumed to have lost its protection against attack.
options.D: The principle of presumption of civilian character of an object in case of doubt requires that it cannot automatically be assumed that any object that appears dubious may be subject to lawful attack, and that a careful assessment of the situation be made to determine if the object is being used to make an effective military contribution.

question: How are indiscriminate attacks regulated under IHL?

options.A: Indiscriminate attacks are permissible in the context of defensive military operations by a state against an invading force.
options.B: Indiscriminate attacks are permissible in non-international armed conflicts.
options.C: Indiscriminate attacks are always prohibited, in any armed conflict.
options.D: Indiscriminate attacks are generally prohibited in armed conflict, depending on the means and methods used.

question: How are indiscriminate attacks defined under IHL?

options.A: An indiscriminate attack does not include attacks that primarily affect the armed forces of the adversary.
options.B: The definition of indiscriminate attacks represents an application of the principle of distinction, the prohibition on attacking civilians and civilian objects, prohibition of weapons that are by nature indiscriminate, and prohibition of means and methods of warfare whose effects cannot be limited as required by IHL.
options.C: This definition of indiscriminate attacks does not apply in non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: The use of weapons whose effects are uncontrollable in time and space and are likely to strike military objectives and civilian objects without distinction is permissible based on the requirements of the prohibition on indiscriminate attacks.

question: To what extent is area bombardment prohibited in IHL?

options.A: Area bombardments are attacks by bombardment by any method or means which treat as a single military objective a number of clearly separated and distinct military objectives located in a city, town, village or other area containing a similar concentration of civilians or civilian objects, and are expressly prohibited.
options.B: The prohibition on area bombardments is applicable in international and non-international armed conflicts.
options.C: Area bombardments constitute a form of indiscriminate attack, and are prohibited.
options.D: An area bombardment is prohibited if it targets a location in which the majority of objects are military objectives, even if also destroying civilian objects.

question: In an armed conflict, what does abiding by the principle of proportionality in attack entail?

options.A: The principle of proportionality in attack prescribes that launching an attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated, is prohibited.
options.B: If the overarching objective of an attack is to win the war, excessive civilian harm may be justified.
options.C: The principle of proportionality does not apply to attacks in non-international armed conflicts as Additional Protocol II does not contain an explicit reference to proportionality.
options.D: According to the International Criminal Court Statute, intentionally launching an attack with the knowledge that such attack will cause incidental loss of life or injury to civilians or damage to civilian object which would be clearly excessive in relation to the concrete and direct overall military advantage anticipated constitutes a war crimes in international armed conflicts.

question: In an armed conflict, what does abiding by the principle of precautions in attack in entail?

options.A: The principle of precautions prescribes that in the conduct of military operations, constant care must be taken to spare the civilian population, civilians and civilian objects.
options.B: In the conduct of military operations, all feasible precautions must be taken to avoid, and in any event to minimize, incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians and damage to civilian objects. Feasible precautions have been defined by States and the Protocols to the CCW as those precautions which are practicable or practically possible, taking into account all circumstances ruling at the time, including humanitarian and military considerations.
options.C: The obligation to take precautions in non-international armed conflicts can be inferred from Article 13(1) of Additional Protocol II which requires that ‘the civilian population and individual civilians shall enjoy general protection against the dangers arising from military operations’.
options.D: When applying the principle of precautions, military commanders and those responsible for planning, deciding or executing attacks have to assess precautions based on relevant information from all sources available to them, including the best possible intelligence on concentrations of civilian persons, important civilian objects, specifically protected objects, the natural environment and the civilian environment of military objectives.

question: What does the IHL rule on target verification entail?

options.A: The rule on target verification is only binding on States in international armed conflicts.
options.B: The rule on target verification requires that parties to the conflict must do everything feasible to verify that targets are military objectives.
options.C: The precautions to be taken in targeting are equivalent to those to be respected in the choice of a military objective, where the attack may only be directed at and is limited to a specified military objective, which is identified as such and is clearly designated and assigned.
options.D: Once an objective is identified as a military objective, it can be lawfully attacked at any subsequent moment, even weeks later.

question: What does the IHL duty to take all feasible precautions in the choice of means and methods of warfare prescribe?

options.A: Parties to the armed conflict are required to take all feasible precautions in the choice of means and methods of warfare with a view to avoiding, and in any event to minimizing, incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians and damage to civilian objects.
options.B: This rule must be applied as part of the proportionality assessment under Rule 14, and not independently.
options.C: Examples of the application of this rule include considerations about the timing of attacks, avoiding combat in populated areas, the selection of means of warfare proportionate to the target, the use of precision weapons and target selection.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the IHL obligation to assess the effects of attack entail?

options.A: Parties to the conflict are required to take all feasible measures to assess whether the attack may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination of these effects, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.
options.B: According to this rule, the same extent of care and precautions which are to be taken in the identification of a military objective must be also taken at this stage of assessment of the effects of attack, including respect for the rule of proportionality.
options.C: The rule whereby each party must do everything feasible to assess whether the attack may be expected to cause excessive incidental damage is not applicable in non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: All of the above.

question: What does the IHL obligation to cancel or suspend an attack require?

options.A: Parties to the conflict must do everything feasible to cancel or suspend an attack if (a) it becomes apparent that the target is not a military objective or (b) that the attack may be expected to cause excessive incidental damage (loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects) in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.
options.B: Disregard for this rule may lead to a violation of the principles of distinction and proportionality.
options.C: This obligation comes into effect in a situation where the distinction, proportionality and precautionary assessments have been carried out and an attack has been planned or is underway, but it now becomes apparent that the target may not be a military objective or there may be excessive incidental damage, at which point as far as possible, the attack must be cancelled or suspended.
options.D: Once a military commander has identified a military objective and done a proportionality assessment, there is nothing that prevents attacking it.

question: What does the IHL obligation to give effective advance warning prior to an attack entail?

options.A: The concept of warnings is not explicitly mentioned in Additional Protocol II, and is therefore not applicable in non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: Parties are not required to give advance warning when circumstances do not permit, such as in cases where the element of surprise is essential to the success of an operation or to the security of the attacking forces or that of friendly forces.
options.C: Parties to the conflict are required to only give advance warning of attacks which may affect the civilian population, no warning is required if no civilians are left in the area to be attacked.
options.D: Even after a warning has been issued, all obligations related to distinction and conduct of hostilities remain applicable to protect civilians who may still remain in the zone of operations.

question: What does the IHL rule on target selection prescribe?

options.A: The rule on target selection prescribes that when a choice is possible between several military objectives corresponding to a similar military advantage, the military objective selected must be that which may be expected to cause the least danger to civilian lives and to civilian objects.
options.B: The rule on target selection is an absolute obligation and applies even when a choice between several military objectives is not possible.
options.C: The rule on target selection is a further specification of the duty to take all feasible precautions in the choice of means and methods of warfare, with target selection also operating as a precautionary measure.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the IHL requirement to take precautions against the effects of attacks include?

options.A: Parties to the conflict are required to take all feasible precautions to protect the civilian population and civilian objects under their control against the effects of attacks.
options.B: This obligation is owed to the civilian population and civilian objects under a party’s control as well as to civilians living under enemy control.
options.C: The requirement to take precautions against the effects of attacks is a general obligation that is read together with the more specific obligations of parties to avoid locating military objectives within or near densely populated areas and to remove civilians and civilian objects from the vicinity of military objectives.
options.D: Examples of active measures that can be taken to protect the civilian population and civilian objects under the control of a party to the conflict include construction of shelters, digging of trenches, distribution of information and warnings, withdrawal of the civilian population to safe places, direction of traffic, guarding of civilian property and the mobilization of civil defence organizations.

question: According to IHL, how is the feasibility of the precautions to be taken assessed, and what if the defender is not able to or does not take any precautions to protect civilians under its control?

options.A: The obligation to take precautions against the effects of attacks is limited to those precautions which are practicable or practically possible, taking into account all circumstances ruling at the time, including humanitarian and military considerations.
options.B: The attacker is at all times prevented from attacking military objectives even if the defender fails to take appropriate precautions or deliberately uses civilians to shield military operations.
options.C: Irrespective of the precautions (or lack thereof) taken by the defender, the attacker is still bound in all circumstances by the duty to take precautions and the principle of proportionality.
options.D: The attacker is not bound by the rules of distinction, proportionality or the duty to take precautions if the defender doesn’t take appropriate precautions or violates IHL.

question: What does the duty to avoid locating military objectives within or near densely populated areas entail under IHL?

options.A: This is an absolute prohibition, and parties can never install military objectives within or near densely populated areas.
options.B: Parties to the conflict must, to the extent feasible, avoid locating military objectives within or near densely populated areas.
options.C: Even dual-use installations, like railway stations and airports must not be located in densely populated areas.
options.D: This obligation is limited to what is feasible in determining the location of military objectives, as demographic changes might cause the area surrounding an existing military base to now be densely populated, in which instance it may not be feasible to immediately move a piece of immovable property like a military base elsewhere.

question: What does the duty to remove civilian persons and objects from the vicinity of military objectives entail?

options.A: Parties to the conflict must, to the extent feasible, remove civilian persons and objects under its control from the vicinity of military objectives.
options.B: This is an absolute requirement and the removal of civilian persons from the vicinity of military objectives must be carried out even if it causes forced displacement without there being security demands for evacuation.
options.C: Removing civilian persons and objects from the vicinity of military objectives becomes all the more necessary where military objectives cannot feasibly be separated from densely populated areas.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the requirement of humane treatment for civilians and persons hors de combat entail under IHL?

options.A: The requirement of humane treatment refers to respect for the dignity of a person and prohibition of ill-treatment.
options.B: This requirement of humane treatment is recognised as a fundamental guarantee in Additional Protocol I and Additional Protocol II.
options.C: The requirement of humane treatment for civilians and persons hors de combat does not extend to captured prisoners of war.
options.D: All of the above.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of adverse distinction entail?

options.A: As per the notion of ‘adverse distinction’, IHL prohibits any discrimination between persons, and no distinction may be made to even provide urgent care to those in need.
options.B: The prohibition of adverse distinction does not apply to the treatment of prisoners of war.
options.C: No distinction may be made among the wounded, sick, and shipwrecked on any grounds other than medical.
options.D: The inclusion of ‘any other criteria’ entails that the list of prohibited grounds of adverse distinction is not exhaustive but illustrative, and may prohibit adverse distinction on additional grounds such as age, state of health, level of education, or family connections of protected persons.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of murder entail?

options.A: The prohibition of murder under this rule extends to persons in the power of a party to the conflict.
options.B: Prohibition of murder is not a fundamental guarantee under Additional Protocol I and Additional Protocol II.
options.C: Unlawful killings resulting from direct attacks on civilians or indiscriminate attacks are prohibited under the conduct of hostilities rules.
options.D: None fo the above.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of torture entail?

options.A: Under IHL, torture is the intentional infliction, by act or omission, of severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, for such purposes as to obtain information or a confession, to punish, intimidate or coerce the victim or a third person, or to discriminate, on any ground, against the victim or a third person.
options.B: For an act to amount as torture, IHL requires that the act be committed ‘by or at the instigation of or with the consent or acquiescence of a public official or other person acting in an official capacity’.
options.C: When distinguishing between torture and cruel/inhuman treatment, torture requires a higher threshold of pain or suffering, which must be ‘severe’ rather than ‘serious’, and the infliction of pain or suffering for torture must be the result of a specific purpose or motivation.
options.D: The prohibition of outrages upon personal dignity only applies to living persons.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of corporal punishment entail?

options.A: The prohibition of corporal punishment does not apply in non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: Corporal punishment can be considered a form of cruel treatment under IHL, or may also fulfil the specific requirements for mutilation or torture.
options.C: Corporal punishment can be considered a form of cruel treatment under IHL, or may also fulfil the specific requirements for mutilation or torture.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of mutilation, medical or scientific experiments entail?

options.A: Consent by the detained person can justify mutilation or medical or scientific experiments.
options.B: Under this rule, the prohibition of mutilation only applies to living persons.
options.C: The only exception to this rule is carrying out any form of mutilation or medical procedure conducive to improving the state of health of the detained person, such as amputation of a gangrenous limb.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of rape entail?

options.A: Sexual violence constitutes acts such as rape, enforced prostitution, indecent assault, sexual slavery, forced pregnancy, enforced sterilization, forced public nudity, sexual harassment such as forced stripping, mutilation of sexual organs, forced marriage, forced inspections for virginity, sexual exploitation, such as obtaining sexual services in return for food or protection, forced abortions, and sex trafficking.
options.B: Rape does not meet the severity threshold to qualify as torture.
options.C: The prohibition of sexual violence is non-discriminatory, and protects men and women, adults and children.
options.D: All of the above.

question: What does the IHL prohibition of slavery entail?

options.A: Enslavement of persons is prohibited in international armed conflicts only.
options.B: The prohibition of slavery is not applicable to those who have taken direct part in hostilities.
options.C: Enslavement is the the exercise of any or all of the powers attaching to the right of ownership over a person and includes the exercise of such power in the course of trafficking in persons, in particular women and children.
options.D: None of the above.

question: Under IHL, what does the prohibition of forced labour entail?

options.A: While the detaining power may utilize the labour of prisoners of war, such as for camp administration, installation or maintenance, this work can have no direct connection to war operations, and rules governing working conditions, pay, and medical supervision must be followed.
options.B: Protected civilians can never be compelled to work.
options.C: In non-international armed conflicts, persons deprived of liberty that are made to work shall benefit from working conditions and safeguards similar to those enjoyed by the local population.
options.D: In international armed conflicts, it is prohibited to compel prisoners of war or protected civilians to serve in the forces of a hostile power or take part in operations of war directed against their own country.

question: Under IHL, what does the prohibition of hostage-taking entail?

options.A: Hostage-taking is defined as the the seizure, detention or otherwise holding of a person (the hostage) accompanied by the threat to kill, injure or continue to detain that person in order to compel a third party to do or to abstain from doing any act as an explicit or implicit condition for the release, safety or wellbeing of the hostage.
options.B: The requisite intent to take hostages must be present at the beginning of detention, otherwise the situation qualifies as detention (unlawful or administrative/judicial).
options.C: The prohibition of hostage-taking is only limited to the taking of civilians.
options.D: The taking of hostages in non-international armed conflicts is not a war crime.

question: Under IHL, what does the prohibition of using human shields entail?

options.A: The requirement that the civilian population and individual civilians shall enjoy general protection against the dangers arising from military operations does not extend to prohibiting the use of human shields in non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: Utilizing the presence of a civilian or other protected person to render certain points, areas or military forces immune from military operations is prohibited.
options.C: The use of human shields requires an intentional co-location of military objectives and civilians or persons hors de combat with the specific intent of trying to prevent the targeting of those military objectives.
options.D: There is no prohibition against the use of prisoners of war as human shields.

question: Under IHL, what does the prohibition of enforced disappearance entail?

options.A: In international armed conflicts, the extensive requirements concerning registration, visits and transmission of information with respect to persons deprived of their liberty are aimed, inter alia, at preventing enforced disappearances.
options.B: The prohibition of enforced disappearance is an express, codified rule in IHL.
options.C: In non-international armed conflicts, the prohibition of enforced disappearance can be inferred from the requirement to take steps to prevent disappearances, including through the registration of persons deprived of their liberty, the requirement of respecting family life, and the requirement to take all feasible measures to account for persons reported missing as a result of armed conflict and to provide their family members with information on their fate.
options.D: Enforced disappearance does not violate the prohibition of arbitrary deprivation of liberty.

question: Under IHL, what does the prohibition of arbitrary deprivation of liberty entail?

options.A: The prohibition of arbitrary deprivation of liberty is not applicable to the detention of medical and religious personnel.
options.B: A civilian may be interned or placed in residence even without posing any risk to the security of the detaining power.
options.C: Procedural requirements to be followed under IHL for lawful deprivation of liberty include ensuring that any person arrested, detained or interned for actions related to the armed conflict is informed promptly of the reasons for arrest/detention in a language they understand.
options.D: Arbitrary deprivation of liberty is compatible with the requirement of humane treatment.

question: Under IHL, what does the right to fair trial entail?

options.A: The right to fair trial is suspended in occupied territory.
options.B: The principle of non bis in idem (no one should be punished for the same act more than once) does not apply to civilian internees.
options.C: Trial of civilians by military courts in occupied territory is a violation of their right to fair trial under IHL.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the IHL principle of legality entail?

options.A: The principle of legality is not applicable to civilian internees, and they can be retroactively tried for acts that were not criminal offences provided for by law prior to the commission of these acts.
options.B: The principle of legality also means that a lighter penalty than the one applicable at the time of commission cannot be imposed, due to a change in law.
options.C: The principle of legality provides the accused with a defence to plead ignorance of the law in force at the time of commission.
options.D: A prisoner of war may be prosecuted for an international crime, under the international law in force, even if the conduct in question was not prohibited under the domestic law of the detaining power at the time of the act.

question: Under IHL, what does the requirement of individual criminal responsibility entail?

options.A: The requirement of individual criminal responsibility negates the possibility of prosecuting individuals for grave breaches on the basis of command responsibility.
options.B: The requirement of individual criminal responsibility as a fundamental rule of criminal procedure is not applicable to penal sanctions in occupied territory.
options.C: The concept of individual criminal responsibility only covers committing and attempting to commit a crime; protected persons cannot be held individually responsible for assisting in, facilitating, aiding or abetting, the commission of a crime.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the prohibition of collective punishment entail under IHL?

options.A: The prohibition of collective punishment is partly an application of the rule that that no one may be convicted of an offence except on the basis of individual criminal responsibility.
options.B: The prohibition of collective punishments only applies to criminal sanctions.
options.C: The prohibition of collective punishments is not a fundamental guarantee applicable to persons hors de combat in non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: For prisoners of war, collective punishment is permitted where the offence is not entirely limited to a particular individual and other prisoners of war are implicated by connivance.

question: What does the requirement of respect for the convictions and religious practices of civilians and hors de combat entail?

options.A: The requirement to respect convictions and religious practices does not extend to civilians in occupied territory.
options.B: No limitations to the right of civilians and hors de combat to practise their religion is permitted, not even for order, security or the rights and freedoms of others.
options.C: Respect for religion and religious practices is reflected in a series of detailed IHL rules concerning burial rites and cremation of the dead, religious activities of prisoners of war and interned persons, and the education of orphaned children or children separated from their parents.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the IHL obligation to respect family rights entail?

options.A: Respect for family life requires, to the degree possible, the maintenance of family unity, contact between family members and the provision of information on the whereabouts of family members.
options.B: The obligation to respect family lives does not extend to interned families.
options.C: Occupying powers have a duty to avoid, as far as possible, separation of members of a family during transfer or evacuations of civilians.
options.D: It is admirable if parties to a conflict facilitate the reunion of dispersed families, but it is not an obligation under IHL.

question: What does the IHL duty of combatants to distinguish themselves from the civilian population entail?

options.A: In order to distinguish themselves from the civilian population, combatants are expected to wear a uniform or a distinctive sign and must carry arms openly.
options.B: Participants of a levée en masse are considered combatants are entitled to prisoner of war status as long as they carry their arms openly and respect IHL.
options.C: Combatants who are not members of uniformed armed forces do not need to wear a permanent distinctive sign or carry their arms openly.
options.D: Members of armed forces must always distinguish themselves from civilians by wearing uniforms, even when not engaged in military operations.

question: What does the IHL rule that combatants engaged in espionage have no right to prisoner-of-war status and may be tried entail?

options.A: This rule applies even to former spies who rejoin their armed forces and are subsequently captured, as they won’t be entitled to prisoner of war status and can be tried for previous acts of espionage.
options.B: The definition of spies also includes combatants who are gathering information while wearing their own military uniform.
options.C: Captured spies are not entitled to the right to fair trial.
options.D: A combatant who is part of the armed forces of the occupied power and gathers or attempts to gather information of military value within the occupied territory shall not be considered as engaging in espionage unless he does so through an act of false pretences or deliberately in a clandestine manner.

question: How does IHL define the status of mercenaries?

options.A: Members of the armed forces of a party to the conflict who are not nationals of that party are considered mercenaries even if they do not fulfil the other criteria listed in the definition of mercenaries, and are not entitled to prisoner of war status if captured.
options.B: Not being entitled to prisoner of war status, the summary execution of mercenaries is permitted.
options.C: A mercenary is defined as a person who: a) is specially recruited (locally or abroad to fight in an armed conflict); b) takes a direct part in the hostilities; c) is motivated to take part in the hostilities essentially by the desire for private gain and is promised material compensation substantially in excess of that paid to combatants in the regular armed forces; d) is neither a national of a party to the conflict nor a resident of territory controlled by a party to the conflict; e) is not a member of the armed forces of a party to the conflict; and f) has not been sent by a state which is not a party to the conflict on official duty as a member of its armed forces.
options.D: States are obliged under IHL to withhold prisoner of war status from mercenaries, and cannot choose to grant prisoner of war status to captured mercenaries.

question: What does the duty to collect wounded, sick, and shipwrecked without distinction entail in armed conflict?

options.A: The duty to collect the wounded, sick, and shipwrecked without distinction is not applicable to fallen combatants that have taken a direct part in hostilities.
options.B: The duty of protecting the wounded, sick, and shipwrecked means coming to their ‘coming to their defence, lending help and support’.
options.C: Parties are not allowed to call upon the civilian population to assist in the search, collection and evacuation of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked.
options.D: None of the above.

question: What does the duty to care for the wounded, sick, and shipwrecked entail in armed conflict?

options.A: Each party to the conflict must use its best efforts to provide protection and medical care for the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, including permitting humanitarian organizations to provide for their protection and care.
options.B: States can never deny humanitarian organisations permission from providing protection and care to wounded and sick persons on its territory.
options.C: No distinction may be made among the wounded, sick, and shipwrecked, not even on medical grounds, and treating persons requiring urgent care first can be considered discriminatory towards others.
options.D: All of the above.

question: What does the obligation to take all possible measures to protect the wounded, sick and shipwrecked from pillage and ill-treatment prescribe in IHL?

options.A: Civilians do not have a duty to respect the wounded, sick, shipwrecked.
options.B: The obligation to take all possible measures to protect the wounded, sick and shipwrecked from pillage and ill-treatment is not applicable in non-international armed conflicts.
options.C: The prohibition of pillage covers both organized pillage, such as authorized or ordered forms of pillage, and individual acts carried out by combatants or civilians.
options.D: None of the above.

question: Under IHL, it is always permissible to:

options.A: Attack military objectives even if the collateral damage to civilian objects is anticipated to be excessive compared to the military advantage.
options.B: Conduct hostilities in a way that constantly ensures protection for the civilian population as much as possible.
options.C: Target economic infrastructure to weaken an enemy's long-term military capabilities.
options.D: Employ any means necessary to achieve military objectives as long as they are effective.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the implications of transnational terrorism on IHL?

options.A: Transnational terrorism often complicates the classification of conflicts under IHL, making it challenging to distinguish between international and non-international armed conflicts.
options.B: Acts of transnational terrorism have led some to question whether existing IHL norms adequately address the protection of individuals in contemporary conflicts.
options.C: Transnational terrorism automatically transforms a non-international armed conflict into an international armed conflict under IHL.
options.D: In the early 2000s, the rise of transnational terrorism has prompted discussions on the need for potential clarification or development of IHL rules relevant to such acts.

question: Does IHL prohibit the deliberate targeting of humanitarian personnel during armed conflicts?

options.A: Only if they are directly participating in hostilities.
options.B: Only in international armed conflicts.
options.C: Yes, under all circumstances, unless and for such time as the directly participate in hostilities.
options.D: No, if they are suspected of supporting enemy forces.

question: During a conflict in a region with significant ethnic tensions, State X deploys its military forces to secure key civilian infrastructure while a non-state armed group with alleged political motives intensifies its attacks on civilian targets. State X unilaterally declares the group as outside the scope of IHL protections due to their 'terrorist methods'. In this scenario, which approach to IHL is most aligned with legal standards?

options.A: State X can refuse IHL protections to the group, as their actions are political and not part of a traditional armed conflict.
options.B: IHL does not apply, as the conflict is primarily characterized by ethnic rather than military objectives.
options.C: IHL protections must apply to all parties involved in the conflict, and State X must comply regardless of the non-state group's motifs or methods.
options.D: The non-state group forfeits all rights under IHL because of their terrorist attacks are on civilian targets.

question: In the context of an international armed conflict, a group of civilians from State X has been documented to occasionally sabotage communication lines used by State Y's military. How should the civilians from State X be treated under IHL during their acts of sabotage?

options.A: They can be targeted at all times regardless of their activities because they are actively supporting State X.
options.B: They are civilians and would lose their civilian protection from attack only if and for such time as they directly participate in hostilities.
options.C: They are considered combatants and thus entitled to prisoner of war status upon capture.
options.D: They can be detained indefinitely without any prodedural safeguards or judicial guarantees because they pose a security threat.

question: Does IHL prohibit the targeting of civilians who are allegedly providing logistic support to combatants in an armed conflict?

options.A: Yes, unless and for such time as the support they provide amounts to directly participating in hostilities.
options.B: Yes, any form of logistic support by civilians to combatants automatically classifies them as lawful targets.
options.C: No, civilians lose their protection only in the absence of political motives behind their logistic support.
options.D: No, targeting civilians who indirectly contribute to combat operations is always allowed under IHL.

question: Does IHL prohibit the targeting of civilian objects in cases where they serve a dual-use function, such as providing military communications?

options.A: IHL prohibits targeting dual-use objects under all circumstances to protect civilian infrastructure.
options.B: IHL allows targeting dual-use objects only if they qualify as a miliatry objective, if the concrete and direct  military advantage outweighs incidental civilian harm, in line with the principle of proportionality, and if other rules of IHL are respected.
options.C: IHL only allows targeting dual-use objects in international conflicts, but not in non-international conflicts.
options.D: IHL categorically prohibits targeting any civilian objects, including dual-use objects, regardless of military necessity.

question: Under what conditions does IHL allow the use of enhanced interrogation techniques that involve ill-treatment during armed conflicts?

options.A: Only when they are authorized by a competent national authority.
options.B: When there is immediate and significant threat to national security that cannot be averted by any other means.
options.C: Never, as IHL prohibits torture and other forms of inhumane treatment in all circumstances.
options.D: When applied proportionally and monitored by an independent body.

question: Which of the following types of targets may meet the definition of a military objective under Article 52 (2) of Additional Protocol I to the Geneva Conventions?

options.A: A factory manufacturing vehicle parts used solely for civil road construction.
options.B: A bridge primarily used for civilian transportation but also used by military convoys.
options.C: A cultural landmark that represents national pride and morale but has no direct military use.
options.D: A hospital treating only combatants injured in the conflict.

question: Under what conditions does IHL consider a dual-use object a military objective?

options.A: When the object is located in a conflict zone and its capture will boost military morale.
options.B: When the object, through its nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and its partial or total destruction, capture or neutralization, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage.
options.C: When it contributes indirectly to the enemy's war effort by supporting the civilian infrastructure.
options.D: When the object can be expected to lower the enemy's determination to fight over time through economic impact.

question: In the context of the principle of proportionality under IHL, what is a crucial factor in determining whether an attack is disproportionate?

options.A: The emotional distress experienced by civilians due to the attack.
options.B: The economic gain expected for the attacking state from the operation.
options.C: The extent to which the concrete and direct military advantage gained would be substantial and immediate, and not excessive as compared to the incidental civilian harm.
options.D: The historical significance of the area or civilian structures affected by the attack.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the principle of proportionality in IHL?

options.A: A military operation must be canceled if the anticipated incidental harm to civilians clearly exceeds the expected military advantage.
options.B: B) The principle of proportionality requires a balancing  between civilian harm and military advantage, considering only direct and immediate effects on civilian populations.
options.C: The attacking party has a duty to take feasible precautions to avoid or minimize incidental harm to civilians.
options.D: Indirect consequences, such as economic disruptions, are relevant when assessing proportionality under IHL.

question: Under IHL, which of the following best describes the obligation of precautionary measures during attacks?

options.A: Precautionary measures require only that military commanders minimize civilian casualties when it is convenient.
options.B: Precautionary measures oblige parties to a conflict to ensure that incidental civilian casualties are unavoidable.
options.C: Precautionary measures mandate that all feasible steps be taken to avoid or minimize civilian harm, considering both military and humanitarian circumstances.
options.D: Precautionary measures allow military operations to proceed without restrictions if the operation is critical to national security.

question: Under IHL, it is always permissible to:

options.A: Target an adversary's military objectives, even if the attack is expected to cause excessive incidental civilian casualties.
options.B: Conduct surprise attacks on civilian infrastructure if they offer indirect support to the enemy's military efforts.
options.C: Attack dual-use objects if their neutralization offers a definite military advantage and incidental civilian harm is not excessive.
options.D: Target civilian populations, as long as done in self-defense against an occupying power.

question: Which of the following scenarios would most likely involve the legal application of the Fourth Geneva Convention's rules on occupation?

options.A: A state temporarily setting up a humanitarian aid post in a foreign territory with the consent of the local government.
options.B: A state's armed forces exercising complete control over foreign territory without armed resistance and intending to administer it, but without a formal declaration of occupation.
options.C: A state's naval fleet blockading foreign waters to restrict maritime trade.
options.D: Multinational peacekeeping forces conducting patrols in a conflict zone under a United Nations mandate.

question: In a situation where State X's military forces have gained effective control over a territory of State Y without encountering armed resistance, but have not replaced  domestic civilian authorities, how should this scenario be categorized under the rules of occupation in IHL?

options.A: This scenario is considered a traditional occupation, as effective control is the main criterion.
options.B: This case does not qualify as an occupation since there is no armed resistance.
options.C: It amounts to occupation, provided the territory is placed under the authority of the invading armed, even without replacing domestic civilian authorities.
options.D: It cannot be considered an occupation unless there is intent to permanently administer the territory.

question: In the context of non-international armed conflicts, which of the following statements best describes the applicability of customary IHL principles concerning the conduct of hostilities?

options.A: Customary IHL principles such as the distinction between combatants and civilians do not apply, as domestic law takes precedence.
options.B: Customary IHL applies but only bind State armed forces.
options.C: Customary IHL principles, including the prohibition of indiscriminate attacks and the principle of proportionality, apply to all parties of a non-international armed conflict, despite their lack of international treaty obligations.
options.D: Customary IHL principles apply only during international intervention in non-international armed conflicts based on a UN mandate.

question: In the context of non-international armed conflicts, which of the following statements about the treatment of civilians who have taken a direct part in hostilities is correct under IHL?

options.A: They have no protection under IHL and can be treated as ordinary criminals.
options.B: They are still considered civilians but lose protection from direct attack during their participation and can be detained.
options.C: They are classified as combatants with full prisoner of war status.
options.D: They are entitled to continue participating in hostilities without facing any legal consequences.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the obligation of States under Common Article 1 of the Geneva Conventions to 'ensure respect' for IHL?

options.A: States must refrain from actions that would assist other States in committing violations of IHL.
options.B: States are required to intervene militarily in another state's conflict to stop IHL violations.
options.C: States must use, to the extent feasible, their influence to persuade other States to adhere to IHL.
options.D: The obligation applies to both international and non-international armed conflicts.

question: According to IHL, under Common Article 1 of the Geneva Conventions, which of the following best describes a positive obligation of States not involved in an armed conflict?

options.A: States must provide military assistance to parties in conflict to uphold IHL.
options.B: States must use their influence to end violations of IHL by the conflicting parties.
options.C: States must remain neutral and refrain from providing any form of support.
options.D: States must enact domestic laws prohibiting all forms of weapon manufacturing.

question: Which of the following statements correctly reflects the obligations of States under Common Article 1 of the Geneva Conventions concerning the obligation to 'ensure respect' for IHL?

options.A: States are required to provide military support to all parties in a conflict to ensure balanced application of IHL.
options.B: States are prohibited from encouraging or assisting in violations of IHL by any party in an armed conflict.
options.C: States must remain neutral in all armed conflicts regardless of IHL violations occurring.
options.D: States have to guarantee the cessation of all IHL violations in conflicts they are not involved in.

question: Under IHL, what is a state's specific obligation under Common Article 1 of the Geneva Conventions concerning its interaction with other States involved in armed conflicts?

options.A: To provide military support to any state requesting assistance, regardless of their adherence to IHL.
options.B: To actively ensure that States do not breach IHL by using diplomatic and economic measures, irrespective of the States' consent.
options.C: To offer economic incentives to States involved in conflicts to encourage compliance with IHL.
options.D: To refrain from intervening in the affairs of States engaged in conflict, allowing them to resolve violations of IHL on their own.

question: A new armed conflict erupts in Region X between State A and a coalition of non-state armed groups. Several NGOs are advocating for the establishment of a new IHL supervision mechanism to oversee compliance. However, some state actors propose reinvigorating the existing International Fact-Finding Commission (IFFC) under Article 90 of Additional Protocol I. Which of the following limitations of the IFFC could be addressed with the parties' consent?

options.A: The IFFC can only intervene in conflicts if expressly invited by a neutral third party.
options.B: The IFFC's competence is restricted to investigating only international armed conflicts unless consent to expand its role is provided by the parties involved.
options.C: The IFFC has the power to impose binding decisions on the parties of a conflict but only in non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: The IFFC's rulings are automatically binding in all armed conflicts unless vetoed by the UN Security Council.

question: Does IHL prohibit the imposition of criminal punishment on members of non-state armed groups merely for participating in hostilities?

options.A: Yes, IHL provides combatant immunity to non-state armed groups under all circumstances.
options.B: No, non-state armed groups can be prosecuted for participation in hostilities unless they comply fully with IHL.
options.C: No, IHL generally allows States to impose criminal punishment on members of non-state armed groups for mere participation in hostilities, regardless of compliance with IHL.
options.D: Yes, but only if the armed group is recognized as a legitimate party to the conflict by international agreement.

question: During an armed conflict involving multiple non-state armed groups, one such group occupies a school building to use as a military base. The government responds by launching an aerial attack on the structure, knowing it will likely result in civilian casualties. Which principle of IHL is directly at risk of being violated in this scenario?

options.A: Principle of Distinction, as civilians and combatants are not clearly distinguished.
options.B: Principle of Proportionality, due to the anticipated civilian harm risks outweighing the military advantage.
options.C: Principle of Military Necessity, as the attack is not essential to achieving a definitive military goal.
options.D: Principle of Humanity, because the use of any force is against IHL policy.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the application of IHL in non-international armed conflicts?

options.A: IHL applies equally to all parties involved in a non-international armed conflict, regardless of the underlying political motivations or ideologies.
options.B: The application of IHL in a non-international armed conflict is contingent upon the recognition of the armed group by the state they are fighting against.
options.C: Violations of IHL by non-state armed groups do not absolve opposing state forces from their own obligations under IHL.
options.D: IHL requires all parties in a Non-international armed conflict to take feasible precautions to protect civilians during hostilities.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the criteria for determining an international armed conflict under IHL?

options.A: An international armed conflict is determined by any difference arising between two States leading to the resort of armed forces, regardless of whether one party acknowledges a state of war.
options.B: A threshold of intensity is required for hostilities to be classified as an international armed conflict between two States.
options.C: The classification of an international armed conflict does not depend on the duration or intensity of the conflict.
options.D: The state of war need not be recognized by either party for an armed conflict to be considered an international armed conflict.

question: Which of the following scenarios would qualify as an international armed conflict under IHL?

options.A: A state declares war on another state but ceases all hostilities immediately following the declaration.
options.B: Armed forces of State A and State B engage in border skirmishes without either state officially declaring war.
options.C: An armed group from State X attacks a military base in State Y with State X's government disavowing involvement.
options.D: The government of State Z is overthrown by a political faction, without any foreign state involvement.

question: Under IHL, which of the following scenarios accurately reflects the classification of an armed conflict as a non-international armed conflict?

options.A: An armed confrontation between two States that denies the existence of any organized armed groups.
options.B: A series of violent confrontations between a state's armed forces and a well-organized non-state actor within that state's territory, meeting the intensity and organization threshold.
options.C: Hostilities between two neighboring States conducted through regular military forces.
options.D: A dispute between criminal gangs within a state occasionally involving state police forces.

question: In the context of IHL, which of the following conditions must be met to classify an armed conflict as a non international armed conflict under Common Article 3?

options.A: The conflict must involve at least two States with official declarations of war.
options.B: The intensity of violence must disrupt significant foreign economic interests.
options.C: There must be protracted armed violence between governmental forces and organized armed groups, with a minimum level of organization and intensity.
options.D: The conflict must occur within a state and involve military force against unarmed civilians.

question: In the context of a non-international armed conflict which legal framework primarily governs the conduct of hostilities?

options.A: The domestic criminal law of the state involved in the conflict.
options.B: Customary International Human Rights Law.
options.C: Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions and customary IHL.
options.D: International Maritime Law.

question: In the scenario of a conflict being classified as a non-international armed conflict which legal obligation distinguishes the treatment of detained individuals under IHL from human rights law?

options.A: Detainees must always be granted immediate access to a lawyer under IHL.
options.B: IHL allows indefinite detention without trial during a non-international armed conflict.
options.C: IHL state and non-state parties to treat all detainees humanetly and establishes minimum standards for their treatment.
options.D: Under IHL, detainees are subject to trial by military courts only.

question: Under IHL, in what situation can a state rightfully classify an ongoing non-international armed conflict as a 'counter-terrorism' operation, thereby negating the application of IHL?

options.A: When the non-state armed group controls no significant territory and poses no real threat to the stability of the state.
options.B: When the state believes that applying IHL would legitimize the non-state armed group and internationally recognize them.
options.C: When the conflict occurs entirely within the borders of a single state and there is international recognition of the terrorist status of the non-state actor.
options.D: None of the above, as IHL is applicable based on factual conditions constituting an armed conflict, not based on political considerations or declarations.

question: Under IHL, which of the following scenarios accurately demonstrates the principle that the application of IHL does not affect the legal status of non-state armed groups involved in a non-international armed conflict?

options.A: A government recognizing a non-state armed group as a legitimate political entity due to its compliance with IHL norms.
options.B: A state prosecuting members of a non-state armed group for crimes despite the existence of a Non-international armed conflict.
options.C: A non-state armed group being granted immunity from prosecution due to its adherence to Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions.
options.D: Non-state armed groups automatically gaining state-like legal rights upon acknowledgment of a Non-international armed conflict.

question: Under IHL, which of the following scenarios correctly illustrates the application of human rights extraterritorially during a non-international armed conflict?

options.A: A state detaining combatants from an opposing non-state group in territory outside its borders can apply human rights law as a substitute for IHL.
options.B: A state carrying out military operations in a foreign country must apply its human rights obligations extraterritorially in relation to detention practices.
options.C: Non-state armed groups, when detaining individuals in a foreign state, must provide procedural safeguards as required by international human rights treaties.
options.D: States involved in a coalition within a multinational non-international armed conflict must adhere exclusively to the domestic legal provisions of the host country for detention and use of force.

question: In a non-international armed conflict, an non-State armed group detains soldiers from the national army during an incursion, moving them to a location outside the state's borders where it exerts effective control. The group argues it is not bound by human rights extraterritorially. Which of the following statements correctly reflects their obligations under IHL and human rights law?

options.A: The non-state actor is bound by human rights law extraterritorially and must provide full judicial guarantees to the detained soldiers.
options.B: The non-state actor is not bound by any international laws because human rights obligations do not apply extraterritorially to non-state actors.
options.C: The non-state actor must at least ensure humane treatment of the detainees under Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions, regardless of extraterritorial application of human rights law.
options.D: The detained soldiers are entitled to the same protections as prisoners of war, and the non-state actor must observe all obligations under the Third Geneva Convention.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the legal and policy considerations of extraterritorial targeting of individuals under IHL?

options.A: Extraterritorial targeting always requires a prior assessment under the ius ad bellum to evaluate the lawfulness of the resort to force.
options.B: In situations outside of armed conflict, human rights law dictates that lethal force may only be used if other means are ineffective.
options.C: Persons directly participating in hostilities can automatically be targeted in any state they enter, regardless of the state's belligerent status.
options.D: If IHL is deemed applicable, the principle of proportionality under IHL mandates that harm to civilians should not be excessive in relation to the direct military advantage anticipated.

question: In an ongoing non-international armed conflict, State X targets an individual who is believed to be directing hostile operations against it, but who is currently located in the territory of a non-belligerent State Y. Assuming the ius ad bellum requirements have been met, what legal framework primarily governs the lawfulness of targeting this individual under IHL?

options.A: The individual is targetable under IHL rules because they carry the Non-international armed conflict with them to State Y, allowing for conduct of hostilities.
options.B: The individual can be targeted under State Y's domestic law since it assumes priority over IHL in a non-belligerent territory.
options.C: The use of force must be assessed under human rights law standards in State Y due to the absence of armed conflict in its territory.
options.D: The individual is protected by IHL rules as a civilian, as the non-international armed conflict does not extend to State Y.

question: In an ongoing non-international armed conflict, a humanitarian organization seeks to deliver food supplies to civilians in a besieged area controlled by a non-state armed group. The state government has so far denied requests for access on  grounds of national security, despite reports of starvation among the civilian population. Which statement accurately reflects the obligations of the parties under IHL?

options.A: The state can indefinitely deny humanitarian access if it believes there is a national security risk.
options.B: The non-state armed groupis not the territoriyal covereign and must not ensure the civilian population receives adequate supplies.
options.C: The state must not arbitrarily refuse humanitarian access if the conditions are met and the population is in dire need.
options.D: Humanitarian organizations can disregard state consent if they have evidence of starvation.

question: Under what conditions does IHL classify a state as an occupying power?

options.A: When it has formal recognition by the international community as an occupying force.
options.B: When it exercises actual and effective control over a foreign territory, even if it lacks a formal declaration of occupation.
options.C: When it has expressed its intent to administer the occupied territory for an indefinite period.
options.D: Only when there is a complete cessation of hostilities in the occupied region.

question: Under the law of occupation, which of the following conditions is essential for determining the beginning of an occupation?

options.A: The formal declaration of occupation by the invading state.
options.B: The presence of foreign troops in the territory regardless of their level of control.
options.C: The establishment of effective control by foreign military forces over a territory.
options.D: The recognition of the occupation by the United Nations Security Council.

question: A multinational force operating under UN command is conducting active combat operations against a non-state armed group in a host country with the consent of the host government. During an engagement, the UN force captures several members of the non-state armed group. Under IHL, how should the captured individuals be treated, and which legal framework applies?

options.A: They should be treated according to the Geneva Conventions with prisoner of war status since they are part of an armed group.
options.B: They should be considered as ordinary criminals under the host country's domestic law, and IHL does not apply.
options.C: As the conflict is non-international, Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions applies, ensuring humane treatment without specific combatant status.
options.D: They should be treated under the IHL framework for international armed conflicts since a multinational force is involved.

question: In the context of IHL, which responsibility do States have when private military or security companies (PMSCs) are involved in armed conflicts?

options.A: Ensuring PMSCs are only involved in humanitarian aid activities.
options.B: Ensuring PMSCs have equal access to all zones of conflict.
options.C: Ensuring PMSCs adhere to IHL.
options.D: Ensuring PMSCs can operate with full independence from state regulation.

question: Which of the following correctly reflects the responsibility of States regarding the operations of Private Military and Security Companies (PMSCs) during armed conflict?

options.A: States have no responsibility for PMSCs as they are considered private entities.
options.B: States are solely responsible for human rights abuses committed by PMSCs within their territory.
options.C: States are in particular responsible for ensuring PMSCs adhere to IHL when contracted by or operating within their jurisdiction.
options.D: States must only ensure that PMSCs are registered and licensed to operate during armed conflict.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the application of IHL to cyber operations in armed conflict?

options.A: IHL imposes limits on cyber operations even if they do not result in physical damage, as long as they disrupt military functions.
options.B: Cyber operations must be attributed to a state or non-state actor for IHL to apply.
options.C: Cyber operations targeting civilian infrastructure is always lawful under IHL if no physical destruction occurs.
options.D: The principles of distinction and proportionality must be considered in cyber operations, similar to traditional attacks.

question: Under IHL, it is  permissible to deploy new technologies of warfare if:

options.A: They are used exclusively in cyber operations targeting civilian infrastructure.
options.B: Their effects are fully compliant with the rules and principles on the conduct of hostuilities, especially distinction and proportionality, regardless of the technology.
options.C: They result in no physical destruction, making their impact reversible.
options.D: They are utilized by autonomous systems capable of independent decision-making.

question: Under IHL, what is the primary legal consideration when assessing the use of explosive weapons in densely populated areas?

options.A: The economic cost of collateral damage to civilian infrastructure.
options.B: Whether the weapon system used has been universally banned by international treaties.
options.C: The ability pf the operator to distinguish between military objectives and civilians, and the feasibility of minimizing incidental harm.
options.D: The historical precedent of using similar weapons in past conflicts and their outcomes.

question: In the midst of an urban conflict in City Z, a military commander decides to deploy artillery shells with wide impact explosives against a fortified position allegedly held by enemy combatants, though the area is known to also contain civilian structures and inhabitants. Which of the following considerations must be made under IHL to determine the legality of this attack?

options.A: The sheer number of enemy combatants expected to be neutralized regardless of civilian presence.
options.B: Whether the harm to civilians would be excessive in relation to the anticipated concrete and direct military advantage.
options.C: The type of weapon used is inherently illegal, making any attack in a populated area unjustifiable.
options.D: The historical accuracy of previous artillery uses in similar contexts.

question: In a scenario where a group of civilians is supplying weapons to a military faction during an ongoing combat operations, under what conditions do these civilians lose their protection from direct attack?

options.A: Civilians lose protection for as long as military supplies continue to be delivered, irrespective of their involvement in hostilities.
options.B: Civilians lose protection only during each specific act of delivering weapons, as this constitutes direct participation in hostilities.
options.C: Civilians never lose protection from direct attack because supplying weapons is considered a non-combat activity.
options.D: Civilians lose protection indefinitely once they have aided in military activities, irrespective of direct participation.

question: Under IHL, which of the following criteria do not apply when determining if a specific act constitutes direct participation in hostilities?

options.A: The act must have a direct causal link to the harm inflicted.
options.B: The act must be intended to provoke psychological distress among civilians.
options.C: The act must be likely to adversely affect the military operations of a party to an armed conflict.
options.D: The act must be specifically designed in support of a party to the conflict.

question: Under the Arms Trade Treaty, what is the primary legal criterion that States must assess before authorizing the transfer of conventional arms?

options.A: The financial profitability of the arms transfer for the exporting state.
options.B: The environmental impact of transferring arms to the recipient state.
options.C: The likelihood that the arms will be used to commit or facilitate serious violations of IHL.
options.D: The political affiliation of the recipient state with the exporting state.

question: Which aspect of the Arms Trade Treaty is aimed at ensuring that arms transfers do not contribute to violations of IHL?

options.A: Mandating States to assess the potential for technological innovation in the arms trade.
options.B: Requiring States to evaluate the likelihood of serious violations of IHL by recipients before authorizing arms transfers.
options.C: Encouraging States to focus solely on economic benefits of arms exports.
options.D: Obliging States to achieve a certain quota of international arms trade annually.

question: In the context of non-international armed conflicts, what is a potential consequence of designating a non-state armed group as 'terrorist' under domestic and international policy frameworks?

options.A: It guarantees the legal protection for humanitarian aid workers under both IHL and domestic law.
options.B: It facilitates the negotiation and reconciliation process between state and non-state parties.
options.C: It complicates humanitarian activities by potentially criminalizing support or assistance provided to civilian populations in conflict zones.
options.D: It makes the non-state armed group eligible for amnesty and recognition under international law.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the triggers for the applicability of IHL?

options.A: A temporary cessation of hostilities between two States automatically ends the applicability of IHL.
options.B: IHL applies in non-international armed conflicts  when the non-State armed group(s) has a sufficient level of organization and the conflict has a certain intensity of conflict.
options.C: The presence of foreign armed forces in a foreign territory, in a position to exercise authority over that territory (or parts of it), without the consent of the effective local government at the time of the invasion - and where that government has been, or can be, rendered substantially or completely incapable of exerting its powers - can trigger the applicability of occupation law under IHL.
options.D: An International Armed Conflict  is triggered regardless of the scale of force used between States.

question: During a prolonged conflict with a non-state armed group, State X asserts that the armed confrontation has ended because a temporary ceasefire has been agreed upon, and hostilities have ceased for several weeks. However, State X continues to maintain a substantial military presence in the region for defensive purposes. When does the applicability of IHL to this non-international armed conflict cease?

options.A: As soon as the Parties agree to a temporary ceasefire, because it signifies the end of hostilities.
options.B: When there is a complete cessation of hostilities and no real risk of their resumption, with no further military presence of hostile nature.
options.C: If the opposing non-state armed group has not agreed to disband, IHL continues to apply indefinitely.
options.D: IHL will cease to apply only as soon as State X and the non-state armed group sign a peace treaty.

question: Considering the territorial applicability of IHL in Non-International Armed Conflicts , under which circumstances IHL might extend to the territory of a non-belligerent State?

options.A: When a member of an armed group  travels to a non-belligerent State for non-combat purposes such as diplomacy.
options.B: If the non-belligerent State provides logistical support to one of the parties in the non-international armed conflict, thus becoming an indirect participant.
options.C: When the conditions necessary to constitute a separate non-international armed conflict in the territory of the non-belligerent State are present.
options.D: If a civilian from a non-belligerent State is harmed due to misinformation during the conflict between two parties in a non-international armed conflict.

question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the relationship between IHL and counterterrorism measures?

options.A: IHL applies only if the acts of violence by a non-State group reach the threshold of a Non-International Armed Conflict .
options.B: Acts that are lawful attacks against military objectives under interntional humanitarian law cannot be deemed 'terrorist' under international legal frameworks governing terrorism.
options.C: IHL prohibits certain acts of terrorism in both international and non-international armed conflicts.
options.D: A party to a conflict under IHL can be both a belligerent (with the same rights and obligations under IHL as the others) and be designated as a 'terrorist' by States.

question: Under what conditions does IHL consider the actions of multinational forces sufficient to determine that they have become a party to a pre-existing non-international armed conflict , according to the ICRC's support-based approach to conflict classification?

options.A: When their involvement is limited to humanitarian aid and does not include military operations.
options.B: Only when multinational forces provide logistical and financial support without direct engagement in hostilities.
